div.p: The honest whore, with, the humours of the patient man, and the longing wife. Tho. Dekker.

div.head: Actus primus.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter at one door a funeral, a coronet lying on the hearse, scutcheons and garlands hanging on the sides, attended by Gasparo Trebatzi, Duke of Millan, Castruchio, Sinezi. Pioratto Fluello, and others at another door. Enter Hipolito in discontented appearance: Matheo a gentleman his friend, labouring to hold him back.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Behold, yond comet shows his head again;
Twice hath he thus at cross-turns thrown on us
Prodigious looks: twice hath he troubled
The waters of our eyes. See, he's turned wild;
Go on in god's name.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: On afore there ho.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Kinsmen and friends, take from your manly sides
Your weapons to keep back the desperate boy
From doing violence to the innocent dead.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: I pry thee dear Matheo.

sp.speaker: Matheo
sp.l: Come, you're mad.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.l: I do arrest thee murderer: set down.
Villains set down that sorrow, 'tis all mine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do beseech you all, for my blood's sake
Send hence your milder spirits, and let wrath
Join in confederacy with your weapons points;
If he proceeds to vex us, let your swords
Seek out his bowels: funeral grief loathes words.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Set on.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Set down the body.

sp.speaker: Mat:
sp.l: O my lord?
You're wrong: i'th open street? you see she's dead.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.l: I know she is not dead.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Frantic young man,
Wilt thou believe these gentlemen? pray speak:
thou dost abuse my child, and mockest the tears
That here are shed for her: if to behold
Those roses withered, that set out her cheeks:
That pair of stars that gave her body light,
Darkened and dim for ever: all those rivers
That fed her veins with warm and crimson streams,
Frozen and dried up: if these be signs of death,
Then is she dead. Thou unreligious youth,
Art not ashamed to empty all these eyes
Of funeral tears, (A debt due to the dead,)
As mirth is to the living: shamest thou not
To have them stare on thee? hark, thou art cursed
Even to thy face, by those that scarce can speak.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What wouldst thou have? is she not dead?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O, you ha' killed her by your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Admit I had, thou killst her now again;
And art more savage than a barbarous Moor.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Let me but kiss her pale and bloodless lip.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Or if not touch her, let me look on her.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: As you regard your honour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Honour! smoke.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Or if you loved her living, spare her now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ay, well done sir, you play the gentleman:
Steal hence: 'tis nobly done: away: I'll join
My force to yours, to stop this violent torment:
Pass on. Exeunt with funeral.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Matheo, thou dost wound me more.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I give you physic noble friend, not wounds,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O well said, well done, a true gentleman:
Alack, I know the sea of lover's rage
Comes rushing with so strong a tide: it beats
And bears down all respects of life, of honour,
Of friends, of foes, forget her gallant youth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Forget her?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nam, na, be but patient:
For why death's hand hath sued a strict divorce
twixt her and thee: what's beauty but a corse?
What but fair sand-dust are earth's purest forms:
Queens bodies are but trunks to put in worms.

sp.speaker: Mathew
sp.p: Speak no more sentences, my good lord, but slip hence; you see they are but fits, I'll rule him I warrant ye. Ay, so, tread gingerly, your grace is here somewhat too long already. 'sblood the jest were now, if having ta'en some knocks o'th pate already, he should get loose again, and like a mad ox, toss my new black cloaks into the kennel. I must humour his lordship: my lord Hipolito, is it in your stomach to go to dinner?

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.p: Where is the body?

sp.speaker: Matheo
sp.p: The body, as the Duke spoke very wisely, is gone to be wormed.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: I cannot rest, I'll meet it at next turn,
I'll see how my love looks,Mathaeo holds him ins arms

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: How your love looks? worse than a scarecrow, wrestle not with me: the great fellow gives the fall for a ducat.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.p: I shall forget myself.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: Pray do so, leave yourself behind yourself, and go whither you will. Sfoot, do you long to have base rogues that maintain a saint Anthony's fire in their noses (By nothing but two penny ale) make ballads of you? if the Duke had but so much mettle in him, as is in a cobbler's awl, he would ha' been a vexed thing: he and his train had blown you up, but that their powder has taken the wet of cowards: you'll bleed three pottles of Aligant, by this light, if you follow 'em, and then we shall have a hole made in a wrong place, to have surgeons roll thee up like a baby in swaddling clouts.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.p: What day is today, Mathaeo?

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: Yea marry, this is an easy question: why today is, let me see, Thursday.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.p: O, Thursday.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: Here's a coil for a dead commodity, sfoot women when they are alive are but dead commodities, for you shall have one woman lie upon many men's hands.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.p: She died on Monday then.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p:
And that's the most villainous day of all the week to die in: and she was well, and eat a mess of water-gruel on
Monday morning.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: Ay, it cannot be,
Such a bright taper should burn out so soon.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: O yes my lord, so soon: why I ha' known them, that at dinner have been as well, and had so much health, that they were glad to pledge it, yet before three o'clock have been found dead drunk.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: On Thursday buried! and on Monday died,
Quick haste by’r lady: sure her winding sheet
Was laid out fore her body, and the worms
That now must feast with her, were even bespoke,
And solemnly invited like strange guests.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: Strange feeders they are indeed my lord, and like your jester or young courtier, will enter upon any man's trencher without bidding.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: Cursed be that day for ever that robbed her
Of breath, and me of bliss, henceforth let it stand
Within the wizard's book (The calendar)
Marked with a marginal finger, to be chosen
By thieves, by villains, and black murderers,
As the best day for them to labour in.
If henceforth this adulterous bawdy world
Be got with child with treason, sacrilege,
Atheism, rapes, treacherous friendship, perjury,
Slander, (The beggar's sin) lies, (Sin of fools)
Or any other damned impieties,
On Monday let 'em be delivered:
I swear to thee Mathaeo, by my soul.
Hereafter weekly on that day I'll glue
Mine eyelids down, because they shall not gaze
On any female cheek. And being locked up
In my close chamber, there I'll meditate
On nothing but my Infaelice's end,
Or on a dead man's scull draw out mine own.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: You'll do all these good works now every Monday, because it is so bad: but I hope upon Tuesday morning I shall take you with a wench.

sp.speaker: Hipolito
sp.l: If ever whilst frail blood through my veins run,
on woman's beams I throw affection,
Save her that's dead: or that I loosely fly
To'th shore of any other wafting eye,
Let me not prosper heaven. I will be true,
Even to her dust and ashes: could her tomb
Stand whilst I lived so long, that it might rot,
That should fall down, but she be never forgotten.

sp.speaker: Mathaeo
sp.p: If you have this strange monster, honesty, in your belly, why so jig-makers and chroniclers shall pick something out of you: but and I smell not you and a bawdy house out within these ten days, let my nose be as big as an English bag-pudding: I'll follow your lordship, though it be to the place aforenamed. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Fustigo in some fantastic sea-suite at one door, a porter meets him at another.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: How now porter, will she come?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: If I may trust a woman sir, she will come.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: There's for thy pains, godamercy, if ever I stand in need of a wench that will come with a wet finger, porter, thou shalt earn my money before any clarissimo in Milan; yet so god sa me she's mine own sister body and soul, as I am a christian gentleman; farewell, I'll ponder till she come: thou hast been no bawd in fetching this woman, I assure thee.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: No matter if I had sir, better men than porters are bawds.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: O God sir, many that have born offices. But porter, art sure thou wentest into a true house?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: I think so, for I met with no thieves.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay but art sure it was my sister Viola.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: I am sure by all superscriptions it was the party you ciphered.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Not very tall.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: Nor very low, a middling woman.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: 'Twas she faith, 'twas she, a pretty plump cheek like mine.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: At a blush, a little very much like you.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p:
God's so, I would not for a ducat she had kicked up her heels, for I ha' spent an abomination this voyage, marry I did it amongst sailors and gentlemen: there's a little modicum
more porter for making thee stay, farewell honest porter.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: I am in your debt sir, God preserve you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Not so neither, good porter, god's lid, yonder she coms. Sister Viola, I am glad to see you stirring: it's news to have me here, is't not sister?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Yes trust me: I wondered who should be so bold to send for me, you are welcome to Milan brother.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Troth sister I heard you were married to a very rich chuff, and I was very sorry for it, that I had no better clothes, and that made me send: for you know we milliners love to strut upon Spanish leather. And how does all our friends?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Very well; you ha' travelled enough now, I trow, to sow your wild oats.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: A pox on 'em; wild oats, I ha' not an oat to throw at a horse, troth sister I ha' sowed my oats, and reaped 200. ducats if I had 'em, here, marry I must entreat you to lend me some thirty or forty till the ship come, by this hand I'll discharge at my day, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: These are your old oaths.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Why sister, do you think I'll forswear my hand?

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Well, well, you shall have them: put yourself into better fashion, because I must employ you in a serious matter.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I'll swear like a horse if I like the matter.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: You ha' cast off all your old swaggering humours.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I had not sailed a league in that great fishpond (The sea) but I cast up my very gall.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: I am the more sorry, for I must employ a true swaggerer.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay by this iron sister, they shall find I am powder and touchbox, if they put fire once into me.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Then lend me your ears.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Mine ears are yours dear sister.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: I am married to a man that has wealth enough, and wit enough.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: A linen draper I was told sister.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p:
Very true, a grave citizen; I want nothing that a wife can wish from a husband: but here's the spite, he has
not all things belonging to a man.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: God's my life, he's a very mandrake, or else (God bless us) one a these whiblins, and that's worse, and then all the children that he gets lawfully of your body sister, are bastards by a statute.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: O you run over me too fast brother, I have heard it often said, that he who cannot be angry, is no man. I am sure my husband is a man in print, for all things else, save only in this, no tempest can move him.

sp.speaker: Fist.
sp.p: 'Slid, would he had been at sea with us, he should ha' been moved and moved again, for I'll be sworn la, our drunken ship reeled like a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: No loss of goods can increase in him a wrinkle, no crabbed language make his countenance sour, the stubbornness of no servant shake him, he has no more gall in him than a dove, no more sting than an ant: musician will he never be, (Yet I find much music in him,) but he loves no frets, and is so free from anger, that many times I am ready to bite off my tongue, because it wants that virtue which all women's tongues have (To anger their husbands:) brother, mine can by no thunder: turn him into a sharpness.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Belike his blood sister, is well brewed then.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: I protest to thee Fustigo, I love him most affectionately, but I know not — I ha' such a tickling within me — such a strange longing; nay, verily I do long.

sp.speaker: Fustigo
sp.p: Then you're with child sister, by all signs and tokens; nay, I am partly a physician, and partly something else. I ha' read Albertus Magnus, and Aristotle's emblems.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: You're wide ath' bow hand still brother: my longings are not wanton, but wayward: I long to have my patient husband eat up a whole porcupine, to the intent, the bristling quills may stick about his lips like a Flemish, mustacho, and be shot at me: I shall be leaner than the new moon, unless I can make him born mad.

sp.speaker: Fust:
sp.p: Sfoot half a quarter of an hour does that: make him a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Puh, he would count such a cut no unkindness.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: The honester citizen he, then make him drunk and cut off his beard.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Fie, fie, idle, idle, he's no Frenchman, to fret at the loss of a little scald hair. No brother, thus it shall be, you must be secret.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: As your midwife I protest sister, or a barber-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Repair to the tortoise here in s. Christopher's street, I will send you money, turn yourself into a brave man: instead of the arms of your mistress, let your sword and your military scarf hang about your neck.

sp.speaker: Fust:
sp.p: I must have a great horseman's French feather too sister.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: O, by any means, to show your light head, else your hat will sit like a coxcomb: to be brief, you must be in all points a most terrible wide-mouthed swaggerer.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay, for swaggering points let me alone.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Resort then to our shop, and (In my husband's presence) kiss me, snatch rings, jewels, or any things so you give it back again brother in secret.

sp.speaker: Fust:
sp.p: By this hand sister.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Swear as if you came but new from knighting.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay, I'll swear after 400. a year.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Swagger worse than a lieutenant among freshwater soldiers, call me your love, your ingle, your cousin, or so; but sister at no hand.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: No, no, it shall be cousin, or rather coz, that's the gulling word between the citizens' wives and their old dames, that man 'em to the garden; to call you one a mine ants, sister, were as good as call you arrant whores no, no, let me alone to cozen you rarely.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Has heard I have a brother, but never saw him, therefore put on a good face.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: The best in Milan I warrant.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Take up wares, but pay nothing, rifle my bosom, my pocket, my purse, the boxes for money to dice with all; but brother, you must give all back again in secret.

sp.speaker: Fustigo
sp.p: By this welkin that here roars? I will, or else let me never know what a secret is: why sister do you think I'll coney-catch you, when you are my cousin? God's my life, than I were a stark ass, if I fret not his guts, beg me for a fool.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.p: Be circumspect, and do so then, farewell.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: The tortoise sister? I'll stay there; forty ducats. Exit.

sp.speaker: Viola
sp.l: Thither I'll send: this law can none deny,
Women must have their longings, or they die. Exit.

div.stage: Gasparo the Duke, doctor Benedick, two servants.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give charge that none do enter, lock the doors;
And fellows, what your eyes and ears receive,
Upon your lives trust not the gadding air
To carry the least part of it: the glass, the hourglass.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ah, 'tis mere spent.
But doctor Benedick, does your art speak truth?
Art sure the soporiferous stream will ebb,
And leave the crystal banks of her white body
(Pure as they were at first) just at the hour ▪

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Just at the hour my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Uncurtain her.
Softly sweet doctor: what a coldish heat
Spreads over all her body.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now it works:
The vital spirits that by a sleepy charm
Were bound up fast, and threw an icy rust
On her exterior parts, now 'gin to break:
Trouble her not my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Some stools, you called
For music, did you not? O ho, it speaks,
It speaks, watch sirs her waking, note those sands,
Doctor sit down: a dukedom that should weigh mine
Own down twice, being put into one stale:
And that fond desperate boy Hipolito,
Making the weight up ▪ should not (At my hands)
Buy her i'th tother, were her 〈…〉
Than hers, who makes a dowry up 〈…〉
doctor I'll starve her on the apennine
Ere he shall marry her: I must confess,
Hipolito is nobly born, a man;
Did not mine enemy's blood boil in his veins,
Whom I would court to be my son in law?
But princes whose high spleens for empery swell,
Are not with easy art made parallel.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: She wakes my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Look doctor Benedick.
I charge you on your lives maintain for truth,
Whate'er the doctor or myself aver
For you shall bear hes hence to Bergamo

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: O God, what fearful dreams?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Girl.
Why Infaelisha, how is't now, ha, speak?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: I'm well, what makes this doctor here? I'm well.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou wert not so even now, sickness pale hand
Laid hold on thee even in the deadst of feasting,
And when a cap crowned with thy lover's health
Had touched thy lips, a sensible cold dew
Stood on thy cheeks, as if that death had wept
To see such beauty altered.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: I remember
I sat at banquet, but felt no such change.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou hast forgotten then how a messenger
Came wildly in with this unsavoury news
That he was dead.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: What messenger? who's dead?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hipolito, alack, wring not thy hands.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: I saw no messenger, heard no such news,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Trust me you did sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: La you now.

sp.speaker: 2 servants
sp.l: Yes indeed madam.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: La you now, 'tis well God knows.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: You ha' slain him, and now you'll murder me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Good Infaelice vex not thus thyself,
Of this the bad report before did strike
So coldly to the heart ▪ that the swift currents
Of life were all frozen up.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: It is untrue,
'Tis most untrue, oh most unnatural father ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And we had much to do by arm best cunning,
To fetch life back again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Most certain lady.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why la you now, you'll not believe me, friends,
Sweat we not all; had we not much to do?

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Yes indeed my lord, much ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Death drew such fearful pictures in thy face,
That were Hipolito alive again,
I'll kneel and woo the noble gentleman
To be thy husband ▪ now I 〈◊〉 repent
My sharpness to him ▪ and his family ▪
Nay, do not weep for him, we all must die:
Doctor, this place where she so oft hath seen
His lively presence, haunts her, does it not?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Doubtless my lord it does ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It does, it does.
Therefore sweet girl thou shalt to Bergamo ▪

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Even where you will, in any place there's woe.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A coach is ready, Bergamo doth stand
In a most wholesome air, sweet walks, there's diere,
Ay, thou shalt hunt and send us venison.
Which like some gods in the 〈◊〉 groves ▪
Thine own fair hand shall strike; sirs, you shall teach her
To stand, and how to shoot, ay, she shall hunt:
Cast off this sorrow ▪ in girl, and prepare
This night to ride away to Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: O most unhappy maid. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Follow it close.
No words that she was buried on your lives ▪
Or that her ghost walks now after she's dead;
I'll hang you if you name a funeral

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: He speaks 〈◊〉 lord ▪ so I speak but deadly word. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: And I'll speak 〈…〉 Greek.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Away ▪ look to 〈…〉
Did you observe how 〈…〉
upon his name and death, oh would 'twere true.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: It may my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: May? how? I wish his death.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And you may have your wish ▪ say but the word,
And 'tis a strong spell to rip up his grave:
I have good knowledge with Hipolito,
He calls me friend, I'll creep into his bosom,
And sting him there to death can do't.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Perform it; I'll create thee half mine heir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: It shall be done, although the fact be foul.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Greatness hides sin, the guilt upon my soul.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Cast:
sp.p: Signior Pioratto, signior Fluello, shall's be merry? shall's play the wags now?

sp.speaker: Flu:
sp.p: Ay, any thing that may beget the child of laughter.

sp.speaker: Cast:
sp.p: Truth I have a pretty sportive conceit new crept into my brain, will move excellent mirth.

sp.speaker: Pio:
sp.p: Let's have't, let's have't, and where shall the scene of mirth lie?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: At signior Candido's house, the patient man, nay the monstrous patient man; they say his blood is immovable, that he has taken all patience from a man, and all constancy from a woman.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: That makes so many whores nowadays.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Ay, and so many knaves too.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: To conclude, the report goes, he's so mild, so affable, so suffering, that nothing indeed can move him: now do but think what sport it will be to make this fellow (The mirror of patience) as angry, as vexed, and as mad as an English cuckold.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: O, 'twere admirable mirth, that: but how will't be done signior?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Let me alone, I have a wick, a conceit, a thing, a device will sting him i'faith, if he have but a thimbleful of blood in's belly, or a spleen not so big as a tavern token.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p:
Thou stir him? thou move him ▪ thou anger him? alas, I know his approved temper thou vex him? why he has a patience above 〈…〉 sooner raise a
spleen in an angel ▪ than rough humour in him: why I'll give you instance for it. This wonderfully tempered signior Candido upon a time invited home to his house certain Neopolitan lords of curious taste, and no mean palate, conjuring his wife of all loves, to prepare cheer fitting for such honourable trencher-men. She (Just of a woman's nature, covetous to try the uttermost of vexation, and thinking at last to get the start of his humour) willingly neglected the preparation, and became unfurnished, not only of dainty, but of ordinary dishes. He (According to the mildness of his breast) entertained the lords, and with courtly discourse beguiled the time (As much as a citizen might do:) to conclude, they were hungry lords, for there came no meat in; their stomachs were plainly gulled, and their teeth deluded, and (If anger could have seized a man) there was matter enough i'faith to vex any citizen in the world, if he were not too much made a fool by his wife.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ay, I'll swear for't: sfoot, had it been my case, I should ha' played mad tricks with my wife and family: first I would ha' spitted the men, stewed the maids ▪ and baked the mistress, and so served them in.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Why 'twould ha' tempered any blood but his,
And thou to vex him thou to anger him
With some poor shallow jest ▪

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: 'Sblood signior Pioratto, (You that disparage my conceit) I'll wage a hundred ducats upon the head on't, that it moves him, frets him, and galls him.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Done, 'tis a lay, join golls on't: with us signior Fluello.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Witness: 'tis done ▪
Come, follow me: the house is not far off ▪
I'll thrust him from his humour, vex his breast,
And win a hundred ducats by one jest. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Candido's wife, George, and two prentices in the shop.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Come, you put up your wares in good order here, do you not think you, one peace cast this way, another that way? you had need have a patient master indeed.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Ay, I'll be sworn, for we have a 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: You mumble, do you mumble? I would your master or I could be a note more angry: for two patient folks in a house spoil all the servants that ever shall come under them.

sp.speaker: 1. prentice
sp.p: You patient ▪ I, so is the devil when he is horn mad.

sp.speaker: All three
sp.p: Gentlemen, what do you lack? what is't you buy? See fine hollands, fine cambrics, fine lawns.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: What is't you lack?

sp.speaker: 2. prentice
sp.p: What is't you buy?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Where's signior Candido thy master?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Faith signior, he's a little negotiated, he'll appear presently.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Fellow, let's see a lawn, a choice one sitra.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: The best in all Milan, gentlemen, and this is the piece. I can fit you gentlemen with fine calicoes too for doublets, the only sweet fashion now, most delicate and courtly, a meek gentle calico, cut upon two double affable taffetas, ah, most neat, feat, and 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: A notable-voluble tongued villain.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: I warrant this fellow was never begotten without much prating.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What, and is this she sayest thou?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Ay, and the purest she that ever you fingered since you were a gentleman: look how even she is, look how clean she is, ha, as even as the brow of Cinthia, and as clean as your sons and heirs when they ha' spent all.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Puh, thou talkest, pox on't 'tis rough.

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: How? is she rough? but if you bid pox on't sir, 'twill take away the roughness presently.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ha signior; has he fitted your French curse?

sp.speaker: George
sp.p: Look you gentleman, here's another, compare them I pray, compara virgilium cum Flomero, compare virgins with harlots.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Puh, I ha' seen better, and as you term them, evener and cleaner.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: You may see further for your mind, but trust me you shall not find better for your body. Enter Candido.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O here he comes, let's make as though we pass,
Come, come, we'll try in some other shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: The gentlemen find fault with this lawn, fall out with it, and without a cause too.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Without a cause!
And that makes you to let 'em pass away,
Ah, may I crave a word with you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: He calls us.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Makes the better for the jest.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I pray come near, - you're very welcome gallants,
Pray pardon my man's rudeness, for I fear me
Has talked above a prentice with you, - lawns!
Look you kind gentlemen this—! no: I this:
Take this upon my honest-dealing faith,
To be a true weave, not too hard, nor slack,
But e'en as far from falsehood, as from black.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Well, how do you rate it?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Very constionably, 18. s.a yard.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: That's too dear: how many yards does the whole piece contain think you?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Why, some 17. yards I think, or thereabouts ,
How much would serve your turn? I pray.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Why let me see-would it were better too.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Truth, 'tis the best in Milan at few words.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Well: let me have then a whole pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Ha, ha: you're a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: A pen'orth I say.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Of lawn!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Of lawn? I of lawn, a pen'orth, 'sblood dost not hear? A whole pen'orth, are you deaf?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Deaf? no sir: but I must tell you,
Our wares do seldom meet such customers.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nay, and you and your lawns be so squeamish,
Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Pray stay, a word, pray signior: for what purpose is it I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: 'Sblood, what's that to you: I'll have a penny worth.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A pennyworth! why you shall: I'll serve you presently.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, a pennyworth mistress!

sp.speaker: Mistress
sp.p: A pennyworth! call you these gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: No, no: not there.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: What then kind gentleman? what at this corner here?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No nor there neither.
I'll have it just in the middle, or else not.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Just in the middle: - ha-you shall too: what?
Have you a single penny?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Yes, here's one.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Lend it me I pray.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: An exc'llent followed jest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What will he spoil the lawn now?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Patience, good wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, that patience makes a fool of you: gentlemen, you might ha' found some other citizen to have made a kind gull on, besides my husband.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Pray gentlemen take her to be a woman,
Do not regard her language. — oh kind soul:
Such words will drive away my customers,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Customers with a murrain: call you these customers?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Patience, good wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pax, a your patience.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: 'Sfoot mistress, I warrant these are some cheating companions.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Look you gentleman, there's your ware, I thank you, I have your money; hear, pray know my shop, pray let me have your custom.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Custom quoth a.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Let me take more of your money.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You had need so.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Hark in thine ear, thou'st lost an hundred ducats.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Well, well, I know't: is't possible that homo,
Should be nor man, nor woman: not once moved;
No not at such an injury, not at all!
Sure he's a pigeon, for he has no gall.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Come, come, you're angry though you smother it:
You're vexed i'faith, - confess.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Why gentlemen
Should you conceit me to be vexed or moved?
He has my ware, I have his money fort,
And that's no argument I am angry: no,
The best logician can not prove me so.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: O, but the hateful name of a pennyworth of lawn,
And then cut out, ith' middle of the piece:
Pah, I guess it by myself, would move a lamb
Were he a linen-draper - 'twould i'faith.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Well, give me leave to answer you for that,
Were set here to please all customers,
Their humours and their fancies: - offend none:
We get by many, if we lose by one.
May be his mind stood to no more than that,
A penworth serves him, and amongst trades 'tis found,
Deny a pen'orth, it may cross a pound.
O, he that means to thrive with patient eye,
Must please the devil, if he come to buy.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: O wondrous man, patient 'bove wrong or woe,
How blessed were men, if women could be so.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: And to express how well my breast is pleased,
And satisfied in all: - George fill a beaker. Exit George.
I'll drink unto that gentleman, who lately
Bestowed his money with me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: God's my life,
We shall have all our gains drunk out in beakers,
To make amends for pennyworths of lawn. Enter Georg.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Here wife, begin you to the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I begin to him.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: George, fill't up again:
'Twas my fault, my hand shook. Exit George.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: How strangely this doth show?
A patient man linked with a waspish shrew.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: A silver and gilt beaker! I have a trick to work upon that beaker, sure 'twill fret him, it cannot choose but vex him. Seig ▪ Castruchio, in pity to thee, I have a conceit, will save thy 100. Ducats yet, 'twill do't, and work him to impatience.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Sweet Fluello, I should be bountiful to that conceit.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Well 'tis enough. Enter George.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Here gentleman to you,
I wish your custom, you're exceeding welcome.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I pledge you seig. Candido, - here you, that must receive a 100. Ducats.

sp.speaker: Pior.
sp.l: I'll pledge them deep i'faith Castruchio,
Signior Fluello?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Come: play't off: to me,
I am your last man.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: George, supply the cup.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: So, so, good honest George,
Here signior Candido, all this to you.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: O you must pardon me, I use it not.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Will you not pledge me then?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Yes, but not that:
Great love is shown in little.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Blurt on your sentences, - 'sfoot you shall pledge me all.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Indeed I shall not.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Not pledge me? 'sblood, I'll carry away the beaker then.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The beaker! Oh! that at your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Now by this drink I will.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pledge him, he'll do't else.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: So: I ha' done you right, on my thumble nail,
What will you pledge me now?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You know me sir, I am not of that sin.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Why then farewell:
I'll bear away the beaker by this light.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: That's as you please, 'tis very good.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Nay it doth please me, and as you say, 'tis a very good one:
Farewell signior Candido.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Farewell Candido.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You're welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Heart not moved yet?
I think his patience is above our wit,Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: I told you before mistress, they were all cheaters.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why fool, why husband, why madman, I hope you will not let 'em sneak away so with a silver and gilt beaker, the best in the house too: go fellows make hue and cry after them.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Pray let your tongue lie still, all will be well:
Come hither George, hie to the constable,
And in calm order wish him to attach them,
make no great stir, because they're gentlemen,
And a thing partly done in merriment.
'Tis but a size above a jest thou knowest,
Therefore pursue it mildly, go be gone,
The constable's hard by, bring him along, - make haste again.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O you're a goodly patient woodcock, are you not now? Exit George.see what your patience comes too: every one saddles you, and rides you, you'll be shortly the common stone-horse of Milan: a woman's well helped up with such a meacock, I had rather have a husband that would swaddle me thrice a day, than such a one, that will be gulled twice in half an hour, o I could burn all the wares in my shop for anger.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Pray wear a peaceful temper, be my wife,
That is, be patient: for a wife and husband
Share but one soul between them: this being known,
Why should not one soul then agree in one? Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Hang your agreements: but if my beaker be gone.

div.stage: Enter Castruchio, Fluello, Pioratto, and George.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: O, hear they come.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: The constable sir, let 'em come along with me, because there should be no wondering, he stays at door.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Constable goodman Abram.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Now signior Candido, 'sblood why do you attach us?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: 'Sheart! attach us!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Nay swear not gallants,
Your oaths may move your souls, but not move me,
You have a silver beaker of my wives.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: You say not true: 'tis gilt.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then you say true.
And being gilt, the guilt lies more on you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I hope you're not angry sir.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then you hope right, for I am not angry.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: No, but a little moved.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I moved! 'twas you were moved, you were brought hither.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: But you (Out of your anger and impatience,)
Caused us to be attached.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Nay you misplace it.
Out of my quiet sufferance I did that,
And not of any wrath, had I shown anger,
I should have then pursued you with the law,
And hunted you to shame, as many worldlings
Do build their anger upon feebler grounds,
The moors the pity, many lose their lives
For scarce so much coin as will hide their palm:
Which is most cruel, those have vexed spirits
That pursue lives, in this opinion rest,
The loss of millions could not move my breast.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Thou art a blessed man, and with peace dost deal,
Such a meek spirit can bless a common weal.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Gentlemen, now 'tis upon eating time,
Pray part not hence, but dine with me today.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I never heard a carter yet say nay
To such a motion. I'll not be the first.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Nor I,

sp.speaker: F●u.
sp.l: Nor I,

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: The constable shall bear you company,
George call him in, let the world say what it can,
Nothing can drive me from a patient man. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Roger with a stool, cushion, lookingglass and chasing-dish, those being set down, he pulls out of his pocket, a viol with white colour in it. And 2. boxes, one with white, another red painting, he places all things in order and a candle by them singing with the ends of old ballads as he does it. At last Bellafront (As he rubs his cheek with the cullors, whistles within.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: A non forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: What are you playing the rogue about?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: About you forsooth: I me drawing up a hole in your white silk stocking.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is my glass there? and my boxes of complexion?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
Yes forsooth: your boxes of complexion are here I think: yes 'tis here: here's your two complexions, and if I had all the four complexions. I should ne'er set a good face upon't, some men I see are born under hard-favoured planets as well as women: zounds I look
worse now than I did before, and it makes her face glister most damnably, there's knavery in daubing I hold my life, or else this is only female pomatum.

div.stage: Enter Bellafronte not full ready, without a gown, she sits down, with her bodkin curls her hair, colours her lips.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Where's my ruff and poker you blockhead?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your ruff, your pocket, are engendering together upon the cupboard of the court, or the court-cup-bord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fetch 'em: is the pox in your hams, you can go no faster?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Wood the pox were in your fingers, unless you could leave flinging; catch. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I'll catch you, you dog by and by: do you grumble?
Cupid is a god, as naked as my nailShe sings.
I'll whip him with a rod, if he my true love fail.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: There's your ruff, shall I poke it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes honest

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.l: No stay: pry thee good boy, hold here,
Down, down, down, down, I fall down and arise, down, I never shall arise.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Troth m. then leave the trade if you shall never rise.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What trade? goodman Abram.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Why that, if down and arise or the falling trade.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll fall with you by and by.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: If you do I know who shall smart fort:
Troth mistress, what do I look like now?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Like as you are: a panderly sixpenny rascal.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I may thank you for that: in faith I look like an old proverb, hold the candle before the devil.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Uds life, I'll stick my knife in your guts and you prate to me so: what? She sings.

lg.l: Well met, pug, the pearl of beauty: umh, umh.
How now sir knave, you forget your duty, umh, umh.
Marry muff sir, are you grown so dainty; fa, la, la, etc.
Is it you sir? the worst of twenty, fa la, la, leera la.

sp.p: Pox on you, how dost thou hold my glass?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Why, as I hold your door: with my fingers.

sp.speaker: Hell
sp.p: Nay pray thee sweet honey

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hold up handsomely
Sing pretty wantons warble, etc.we shall ha' guests today.
I lay my little maidenhead, my nose itches so.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I said so too last night, when our fleas twinged me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: So poke my ruff now, my gown, my gown, have I my fall?
Where's my fall Roger? One knocks.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your fall forsooth is behind.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: God's my pittikins, some fool or other knocks.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Shall I open to the fool mistress?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And all these babbles lying thus? away with it quickly, ay, ay, knock and be damned, whosoever you be. So: give the fresh salmon line now: let him come ashore, he shall serve for my breakfast, though he go against my stomach.

div.stage: Roger fetch in Fluello, Castruchio, and Pioratto.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Morrow coz.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: How does my sweet acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Save thee little marmoset: how dost thou good pretty rogue?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, godamercy good pretty rascal.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Roger some light I pry thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: You shall signior, for we that live here in this vale of misery, are as dark as hell. Exit ▪ for a candle.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Good tobacco, Fluello?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Smell? Enter Roger.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: It may be tickling gear: for it plays with my nose already.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's another light angel, signior.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What? yond pied curtal, what's that you are neighing?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I say God send us the light of heaven, or some more angels.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go fetch some wine, and drink half of it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I must fetch some wine gentlemen and drink half of it.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Here Roger ▪

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: No let me send pry thee.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Hold you canker worm.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: You shall send both, if you please signiors.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Stay, what's best to drink a mornings?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Hippocras sir, for my mistress, if I fetch it, is most dear to her.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Hippocras! there then, here's a teston for you, you snake

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Right sir, here's iii.s vi.d for a pottle and a manchet -Ex.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Here's most herculaniam tobacco, ha some acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fah, not I, makes your breath stink, like the piss of a fox. Acquaintance, where supped you last night?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: At a place sweet acquaintance where your health danced the canaries i'faith: you should ha' been there.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I there among your punks, marry fah, hang-em: scorn't: will you never leave sucking of eggs in other folks hens nests.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Why in good troth, if you'll trust me acquaintance, there was not one hen at the board, ask Fluello.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: No faith coz; none but cocks, signior Malavella drunk to thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O, a pure beagle; that horseleech there?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: And the knight, s. Oliver Lollilo, swore he would bestow a taffeta petticoat on thee, but to break his fast with thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: With me! I'll choke him then, hang him mole-catcher, it's the dreamingst snotty-nose.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Well, many took that Lollio for a fool, but he's a subtle fool.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, and he has fellows: of all filthy dry-fisted knights, I cannot abide that he should touch me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Why wench, is he scabbed?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hang him, he'll not live to be so honest, nor to the credit to have scabs about him, his betters have 'em: but I hate to wear out any of his course knighthood, because he's made like an alderman's nightgown, faced all with coney before, and within nothing but fox: this sweet Oliver, will eat mutton till he be ready to burst, but the lean jawed-slave will not pay for the scraping of his trencher.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Plague him, set him beneath the salt, and let him not touch a bit, till every one has had his full cut.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Lord Ello, the gentleman-usher came into us too, marry 'twas in our cheese, for he had been to borrow money for his lord, of a citizen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What an ass is that lord, to borrow money of a citizen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, god's my pity, what an ass is that citizen to lend money of a lord.

div.stage:
Enter Matheo and Hypolito, who saluting the company, as a stranger walks off. Roger comes in sadly behind them,
with a potle-pot, and stands aloof off.

sp.speaker: Matheo.
sp.p: Save you gallants, signior Fluello, exceedingly well met, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Signior Matheo, exceedingly well met too, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And how fares my little pretty mistress?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: E'en as my little pretty servant; sees three court dishes before her, and not one good bit in them: how now? why the devil standst thou so? Art in a trance?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why dost not fill out their wine?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Forsooth 'tis filled out already: all the wine that the signior has bestowed upon you is cast away, a porter ran a little at me, and so faced me down that I had not a drop.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'm a cursed to let such a withered artichoke faced-rascal grow under my nose: now you look like an old ●e ca●, going to the gallows: I'll be hanged if he ha' not put up the money to coney-catch us all.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: No truely forsooth, 'tis not put up yet.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: How many gentlemen hast thou served thus?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: None but five hundred, besides prentices and serving-men.

sp.speaker: Be●.
sp.p: Dost think I'll pocket it up at thy hands?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I fear you will pocket it up.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Fie, fie, cut my lace good servant, I shall ha' the mother presently I'm so vexed at this horse-plum.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Plague, not for a scald pottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Nay, sweet Bellafronte, for a little pigs wash.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Here Roger, fetch more, a mischance. I'faith acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou ungodly puritanical creature.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: For the tother pottle? yes forsooth. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Spill that too: what gentleman is that servant? your friend?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: God's so a stool ▪ a stool, if you love me mistress entertain this gentleman respectively, and bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's very welcome, pray sir sit.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.p: Thanks lady.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p:
Count Hypolito, is't not? cry you mercy signior, you walk here all this while, and we not heard you? let me bestow
a stool upon you beseech you, you are a stranger here, we know the fashions ath' house.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Please you be here my lord. Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: No good Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: You have abandoned the court I see my lord since the death of your mistress, well she was a delicate piece beseech— you sweet, come let us serve under the colours of your acquaintance still: for all that, please you to meet here at my lodging of my coz, I shall bestow a banquet upon you.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I never can deserve this kindness sir.
What may this lady be, whom you call coz?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Faith sir a poor gentlewoman, of passing good carriage, one that has some suits in law, and lies here in an attorney's house.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Is she married?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ha, as all your punks are, a captain's wife, or so? never saw her before, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Never trust me a goodly creature.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: By gad when you know her as we do, you'll swear she is the prettiest, kindest, sweetest, most bewitching honest ape under the pole. A skin, your satin is not more soft, nor lawn whiter.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Belike then she's some sale courtesan.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Troth as all your best faces are, a good wench.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Great pity that she's a good wench:

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Thou shalt ha' i'faith mistress: how now signiors? what? whispering? did not I lay a wager I should take you within seven days in a house of vanity.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: You did, and I beshrew your heart, you have won.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: How do you like my mistress?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Well, for such a mistress: better, if your mistress be not you master.
I must break manners gentlemen, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sfoot you shall not leave us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The gentleman likes not the taste of our company,

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Beseech you stay.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.p: Trust me my affairs beckon for me, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Will you call for me half an hour hence here?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Perhaps I shall.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Perhaps? fah! I know you can swear to me you will,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Since you will press me on my word, I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What sullen picture is this servant?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Its count Hipolito, the brave count.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: As gallant a spirit, as any in Milan you sweet Jew,

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: O he's a most essential gentleman, coz.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Did you never hear of count Hippolito's acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Marymuff a your counts, and be no more life in 'em.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: He's so malcontent! sirrah Bellafronte, and you be honest gallants, let's sup together, and have the count with us: thou shalt sit at the upper end punk.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Punk, you soused gurnet?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: King's truce: come, I'll bestow the supper to have him but laugh.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He betrays his youth too grossly to that tyrant melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: All this is for a woman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A woman! some whore! what sweet jewel is't?

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Would she heard you.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Troth so would I.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: And I by heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay good servant, what woman?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Pah.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pry thee tell me, abusse and tell me: I warrant he's an honest fellow, if he take on thus for a wench: good rogue who:

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Byth' lord I will not, must not faith mistress: is't a match sirs? his night, at th'antelope: ay, for there's best wine, and good boys.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: It's done at th'antelope.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I cannot be there tonight .

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Cannot? byth' lord you shall.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By the lady I will not: shall!

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Why then put it off till Friday: wilt come then coz?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well. Enter Roger.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: You're the waspishest ape. Roger, put your mistress in mind to sup with us on Friday next: you're best come like a madwoman without a band in your waistcoat, and the linings of your kirtle outward, like every common hackney that steals out at the back gate of her sweet knights lodging

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go, go, hang yourself.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Its dinner time Matheo, shall's hence?

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.p: Yes, yes, farewell wench. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Farewell boys: Roger what wine sent they for?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Bastard wine, for if it had been truly begotten, it would not ha' been ashamed to come in, here's vi. s. to pay for nursing the bastard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A company of rooks! O good sweet Roger, run to the poulters and buy me some fine larks.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: No woodcocks?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes faith a couple, if they be not dear.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I'll buy but one, there's one already here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Is the gentleman (My friend) departed mistress?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: His back is but new-turned sir.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I can direct you to him.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Can you? pray.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you please stay, he'll not be absent long.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I care not much.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Pray sit forsooth.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: I'm hot.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: If may use your room, I'll rather walk.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: At your best pleasure-whew-some rubbers there.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Indeed I'll none: - indeed I will not: thanks.
Pretty-fine-lodging. I perceive my friend
Is old in your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Troth sir, he comes
As other gentlemen, to spend spare hours;
If yourself like our roof (Such as it is)
Your own acquaintance may be as old as his.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Say I did like; what welcome should I find?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Such as my present fortunes can afford.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: But would you let me play Matheo's part?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What part?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Why embrace you: dally with you, kiss:
Faith tell me, will you leave him, and love me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am in bonds to no man sir.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Why then,
You're free for any man: if any, me.
But I must tell you lady, were you mine,
You should be all mine: I could brook no sharers,
I should be covetous, and sweep up all.
I should be pleasures usurer: faith I should.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O fate!

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Why sigh you lady? may I know?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: T'has never been my fortune yet to single
Out that one man, whose love could fellow mine.
As I have ever wished it: o my stars!
Had I but met with one kind gentleman,
That would have entombed sin alone, to himself,
For his own private use, although scarce proper:
Indifferent handsome: meetly legged and thighed:
And my allowance reasonable i'faith—,
According to my body by— my troth,
I would have been as true unto his pleasures,
Yea, and as loyal to his afternoons,
As ever a poor gentlewoman could be.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: This were well now, to one but newly fledged,
And scarce a day old in this subtle world:
'Twere pretty art, good birdlime, cunning net:
But come, come, faith confess—: how many men
Have drunk this selfsame protestation,
From that red 'ticing lip?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Indeed not any.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Indeed? and blush not!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: No, in truth not any.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Indeed! in truth!-how warily you swear?
'Tis well: if ill it be not: yet had I
The ruffian in me, and were drawn before you
But in light colours, I do know indeed,
You could not swear indeed, but thunder oaths
That should shake heaven, drown the harmonious spheres,
And pierce a soul (That loved her maker's honour)
With horror and amazement.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Shall I swear?
Will you believe me then?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Worst than of all,
Our sins by custom, seem (At last) but small.
Were I but o'er your threshold, a next man,
And after him a next, and then a fourth,
should have this golden hook, and lascivious bait,
Thrown out to the full length, why let me tell you:
I ha' seen letters sent from that white hand,
Tuning such music to Matheo's ear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Mathaeo! that's true, but believe it, I
No sooner had laid hold upon your presence,
But straight mine eye conveyed you to my heart.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: O, you cannot feign with me, why, I know lady,
This is the common passion of you all,
To hook in a kind gentleman, and then
Abuse his coin, conveying it to your lover,
And in the end you show him a French trick,
And so you leave him, that a coach may run
Between his legs for breadth.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.l: O by my soul!
Not I: therein I'll prove an honest whore,
In being true to one, and to no more.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: If any be disposed to trust your oath,
Let him: I'll not be he ▪ I know you feign
All that you speak, I: for a mingled harlot,
Is true in nothing but in being false.
What! shall I teach you how to loathe yourself?
And mildly too: not without sense or reason.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am content, I would fain loathe myself,
If you not love me.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Then if your gracious blood be not all wasted,
I shall assay to do't.
Lend me your silence, and attention, - you have no soul,
That makes you weigh so light: heaven's treasure bought it,
And half a crown hath sold it: for your body
Is like the common shore, that still receives
All the town's filth. The sin of many men
Is within you, and thus much I suppose,
That if all your committers stood in rank,
They'd make a lane, (In which your shame might dwell)
And with their spaces reach from hence to hell.
Nay, shall I urge it more, there has been known,
as many by one harlot, maimed and dismembered,
As would ha' stuffed an hospital: this I might
Apply to you, and perhaps do you right:
Oh you're as base as any beast that bears,
Your body is e'en hired, and so are theirs.
For gold and sparkling jewels, (If he can)
You'll let a Jew get you with christian:
Be he a Moor, a tartar, though his face
Look uglier than a dead man's scull,
Could the devil put on a humane shape,
If his purse shake out crowns, up then he gets,
Whores will be rid to hell with golden bits:
So that you're crueler than Turks, for they
Sell Christians only, you sell yourselves away.
Why those that love you, hate you: and will term you
Liquorish damnation: wish themselves half sunk
After the sin is laid out, and e'en curse
Their fruitless riot, (For what one begets
Another poisons) lust and murder hit,
A tree being often shook, what fruit can knit?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O me unhappy!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I can vex you more;
A harlot is like Dunkirk, true to none,
Swallows both English, Spanish, fulsome Dutch,
Black-doored Italian last of all the French,
And he sticks to you faith: gives you your diet,
Brings you acquainted, first with monsieur doctor,
And than you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Misery.
Rank, sinking, and most loathsome misery.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Methinks a toad is happier than a whore,
That with one poison swells, with thousands more
The other stocks her veins: harlot: fie! fie,
You are the miserablest creatures breathing,
The very slaves of nature: mark me else,
You put on rich attires, others eyes wear them,
You eat, but to supply your blood with sin,
And this strange curse e'en haunts you to your graves.
From fools you get, and spend it upon slaves:
Like bears and apes, you're baited and show tricks
For money; but your bawd the sweetness licks.
Indeed you are their journey-women, and do
All base and damned works they list set you to:
So that you ne'er are rich; for do but show me,
In present memory, or in ages past,
The fairest and most famous courtesan,
Whose flesh was dearest; that raised the price of sin,
And held it up; to whose intemperate bosom,
Princes, Earls, lords, the worst has been a knight,
The meanest a gentleman, have offered up
Whole hecatombs of sighs, and reigned in showers
Handfuls of gold, yet for all this, at last
Diseases sucked her marrow, then grew so poor,
That she has begged, e'en at a beggar's door.
And (Wherein heaven has a singer) when this idol,
From coast to coast, has leapt on foreign shores,
And had more worship, than th'outlandish whores:
When several nations have gone over her,
When for each several city she has seen,
Her maidenhead has been new, and been sold dear:
Did live well there, and might have died unknown,
And undefamed; back comes she to her own,
And there both miserably lives and dies,
Scorned even of those, that once adored her eyes,
As if her fatal-circled life, thus ran,
Her pride should end there, where it first began.
What do you weep to hear your story read?
Nay, if you spoil your cheeks, I'll read no more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O yes, I pray proceed:
Indeed 'twill do me good to weep indeed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: To give those tears a relish, this I add,
You're like the Jews, scattered, in no place certain,
Your days are tedious, your hours burdensome:
And were't not for full suppers, midnight revels,
Dancing, wine, riotous meetings, which do drown,
And bury quite in you all virtuous thoughts,
and on your eyelids hang so heavily,
They have no power to look so high as heaven,
You'd sit and muse on nothing but despair,
Curse that devil lust, that so burns up your blood,
And in ten thousand shivers break your glass
For his temptation. Say you taste delight,
To have a golden gull from ●ize to see,
To meat you in his hot luxurious arms,
Yet your nights pay for all: I know you dream
Of warrants, whips, and beadles, and then start
At a doors windy creak: think every weasel
To be a constable: and every rat
A long tailed officer: are you now not slaves?
O you have damnation without pleasure for it!
Such is the state of harlots. To conclude,
When you are old, and can well paint no more,
You turn bawd, and are then worse than before:
Make use of this: farewell.

sp.speaker: Bel ▪
sp.l: O, I pray stay.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: See Matheo comes not: time hath barred me,
Would all the harlots in the town had heard me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay yet a little longer. no: quite gone!
Cursed be that minute (For it was no more.
So soon a maid is changed into a whore)
Wherein I first fell, be it for ever black;
Yet why should sweet Hipolito shun mine eyes;
For whose true love I would become pure-honest,
Hate the world's mixtures, and the smiles of gold:
Am I not fair? Why should he fly me then?
Fair creatures are desired, not scorned of men.
How many gallants have drunk healths to me,
Out of their daggered arms, and thought them blessed,
Enjoying but mine eyes at prodigal feasts!
And does Hipolito detest my love?
O, sure their heedless lusts but flattered me,
I am not pleasing, beautiful nor young,
Hipolito hath spied some ugly blemish,
Eclipsing all my beauties: I am foul:
harlot! Ay, that's the spot that taints my soul:
What! has he left his weapon here behind him,
And gone forgetful? O fit instrument
To let forth all the poison of my flesh!
Thy m. hates me, cause my blood hath ranged:
But when 'tis forth, than he'll believe I'm changed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Mad woman, what art doing? Enter Hipo.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Either love me,
Or split my heart upon thy rapier's point:
Yet do not neither; for thou then destroy'st
That which I love thee for (Thy virtues) here, here,
Thou'rt crueler, and killest me with disdain:
To die so, sheds no blood, yet 'tis worse pain. Exit Hipol.
Not speak to me! not bid farewell! A scorn!
Hated! this must not be, some means I'll try.
Would all whores were as honest now, as I. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena 7.
div.stage: Enter Candido, his wife, George, and two prentices in the shop: Fustigo enters, walking by.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: See gentlemen, what you lack? A fine holland, a fine cambric, see what you buy.

sp.speaker: 1. Pr.
sp.p: Holland for shirts, cambric for bands, what is't you lack?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, I lack 'em all, nay more, I lack money to buy 'em: let me see, let me look again: mass this is the shop; what coz! sweet coz! how dost i'faith, since last night after candlelight? we had good sport i'faith, had we not? and when shall's laugh again?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: When you will, cousin.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Spoken like a kind Lacedaemonian: I see yonder's thy husband.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: There's the sweet youth, God bless him.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: And how is't cousin? And how? how is't thou squall?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Well, cousin, how fare you?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: How fare I? troth, for sixpence a meal, wench, as well as heart can wish, with calf's caldrons and chitterlings, besides I have a punch after supper, as good as a roasted apple.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Are you my wives cousin?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: A am, sir, what hast thou to do with that?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O, nothing but you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: The devil's dung in thy teeth: I'll be welcome whether thou wilt or no, I: what ring's this coz? very pretty and fantastical i'faith, let's see it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Puh! nay you wrench my finger.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I ha' sworn I'll have't, and I hope you will not let my oaths be cracked in the ring, will you? I hope, sir, you are not melancholy at this for all your great looks: are you angry?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Angry? not I sir, nay, if she can part
So easily with her ring, 'tis with my heart.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Suffer this, sir, and suffer all, a whoreson gull, to —,

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Peace, George, when she has reaped what I have sown,
She'll say, one grain tastes better of her own,
Then whole sheaves gathered from another's land:
Wit's never good, till bought at a dear hand.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: But in the mean time she makes an ass of somebody .

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: See, see, see, sir, as you turn your back, they do nothing but kiss.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: No matter, let 'em: when I touch her lip,
I shall not feel his kisses, no nor miss
Any of her lip: no harm in kissing is.
Look to your business, pray, make up your wares.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Troth coz, and well remembered, I would thou wouldst give me five yards of lawn, to make my punk some falling bands a the fashion, three falling one upon another: for that's the new edition now: she's out of linen horribly too, troth, sha's never a good smock to her back neither, but one that has a great many patches in't, and that I'm fain to wear myself for want of shift to: prithee put me into wholesome nappery, and bestow some clean commodities upon us.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Reach me those cambrics, and the lawns hither.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: What to do wife? to lavish out my goods upon a fool?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Fool! Sneales eat the fool, or I'll so batter your crown, that it shall scarce go for five shillings.

sp.speaker: 2. Pr.
sp.p: Do you hear sir? you're best be quiet, and say a fool tells you so.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nails, I think so, for thou tellst me.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Are you angry sir, because I named the fool?
Trust me, you are not wife, in mine own house;
and to my face to play the antic thus:
If you'll needs play the madman, choose a stage
Of lesser compass, where few eyes may note
Your actions error; but if still you miss,
As here you do, for one clap, ten will hiss.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Zounds cousin, he talks to me, as if I were a scurvy tragedian.

sp.speaker: 2. prentice
sp.p: Sirrah George, I ha' thought upon a device, how to break his pate, beat him soundly, and ship him away.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Do't.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.p: I'll go in, pass thorough the house, give some of our fellow prentices the watchword when they shall enter, then come and fetch my master in by a wile, and place one in the hall to hold him in conference, whilst we cudgel the gull out of his coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Do't: away, do't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Must I call twice for these cambrics and lawns?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Nay see, you anger her, George, prithee dispatch.

sp.speaker: 2. pr.
sp.p: Two of the choicest pieces are in the warehouse sir.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Go fetch them presently. Exit 1. prentice.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Ay, do, make haste, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Why were you such a stranger all this while, being my wives cousin?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Stranger? no sir, I me a natural milliner born.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I perceive still it is your natural guise to mistake me, but you are welcome sir, I much wish your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: My acquaintance? I scorn that i'faith; I hope my acquaintance goes in chains of gold three and fifty times double: you know who I mean, coz, the posts of his gate are a painting to. Enter the 2. Prentice.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: Signior Pandulfo the merchant desires conference with you.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Signior Pandulfo? I'll be with him straight. Attend your mistress and the gentleman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: When do you show those pieces?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Ay, when do you show those pieces?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Presently sir, presently, we are but charging them.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Come sirrah, you flatcap, where be these whites?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Flat-capt hark in your ear sir, you're a flat fool, an ass, a gull, and I'll thrum you: do you see this cambric sir?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: 'Sfoot coz, a good jest, did you hear him? he told me in my ear, I was a flat fool, an ass, a gull, and I'll thrum you: do you see this cambric sir?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: What, not my men, I hope?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: No, not your men, but one of your men i'faith.

sp.speaker: 1. Pr.
sp.p: I pray sir, come hither, what say you to this? here an excellent good one.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I marry, this likes me well, cut me off some half score yards.

sp.speaker: 2. Pr.
sp.p: Let your whores cut, you're an impudent cox comb, you get none, and yet I'll thrum you. A very good cambric sir.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Again, again, as God judge me: 'sfoot, coz, they stand thrumming here with me all day, and yet I get nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Pr.
sp.p: A word I pray sir, you must not be angry, prentices have hot bloods, young fellows, - what say you to this piece? look you, 'tis so delicate, so soft, so even, so fine a thread, that a lady may wear it.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: 'Sfoot I think so, if a knight marry my punk, a lady shall wear it: cut me off 20. yards: thou'rt an honest lad.

sp.speaker: 1. Pr.
sp.p: Not without money, gull, and I'll thrum you to.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Gull, we'll thrum you.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: O lord, sister, did you not hear something cry thrum? zounds your men here make a plain ass of me.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: What, to my face so impudent?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Ay, in a cause so honest, we'll not suffer
Our master's goods to vanish money less.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You will not suffer them.

sp.speaker: 2. Pr.
sp.l: No, and you may blush,
In going about to vex so mild a breast,
As is our masters.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Take away those pieces.
Cousin, I give them freely.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Mass, and I'll take 'em as freely.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We'll make you lay 'em down again more freely.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Help, help, my brother will be murdered. Enter Can.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How now, what coil is here? forbear, I say.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: He calls us flatcaps, and abuses us.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Why, sirs? do such examples flow from me?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: They are of your keeping sir, alas poor brother.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I faith they ha' peppered me, sister: look, dost not spin? call you these prentices? I'll ne'er play at cards more when clubs is trump: I have a goodly coxcomb, sister, have I not?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Sister and brother, brother to my wife.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: If you have any skill in heraldry, you may soon know that, break but her pate, and you shall see her blood and mine is all one.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A surgeon, run, a surgeon: why then wore you that forged name of cousin?

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Because it's a common thing to call coz, and mingle now adays all the world over.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Cousin! A name of much deceit, folly and sin,
For under that common abused word,
Many an honest tempered citizen
Is made a monster, and his wife trained out
To foul adulterous action, full of fraud.
I may well call that word, a city's bawd.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Troth, brother, my sister would needs ha' me take upon me to gull your patience a little: but it has made double gules on my coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What, playing the woman? blabbing now you fool?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O, my wife did but exercise a jest upon your wit.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, my wit bleeds for't, methinks .

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then let this warning more of sense afford.
The name of cousin is a bloody word.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: I'll ne'er call coz again whilst I live; to have such a coil about it: this should be a coronation day; for my head runs claret lustily.ExitEnter an officer.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: Go with the surgeon to have great respect.
How now, my friend, what, do they sit today?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Yes sir, they expect you at the senate-house.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: I thank your pains, I'll not be last man there. Exit Off.
My gown, George, go, my gown. A happy land,
Where grave men meet each cause to understand,
Whose consciences are not cut out in bribes,
To gull the poor man's right: but in even scales,
Peise rich and poor, without corruptions veils.
Come, where's the gown?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: I cannot find the key sir.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Request it of your mistress.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Come not to me for any key.
I'll not be troubled to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Good wife, kind wife, it is a needful trouble, but for my gown.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Moths swallow down your gown:
You set my teeth an edge with talking on't.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Nay pry thee, sweet, I cannot meet without it,
I should have a great fine set on my head.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Set on your coxcomb: tush, fine me no fines.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Believe me (Sweet) none greets the senate-house, without his robe of reverence, that's his gown.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well, then you're like to cross that custom once,
You get nor key, nor gown, and so depart:
This trick will vex him sure, and fret his heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Stay, let me see, I must have some device,
My cloak's too short: fie, fie, no cloak will do't:
It must be something fashioned like a gown,
With my arms out: o George, come hither George,
I pry thee lend me thine advice.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Troth sir, were it any but you, they would break open chest.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: O no, break open chest! that's a thief's office:
Therein you counsel me against my blood:
'Twould show impatience that, any meek means
I would be glad to embrace. Mass I have got it:
Go, step up, fetch me down one of the carpets,
The saddest coloured carpet, honest George,
Cut thou a hole ith' middle for my neck,
Two for mine arms, nay prithee look not strange.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I hope you do not think sir, as you mean.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Prithee about it quickly, the hour chides me:
Warily George, softly, take heed of eyes,Exit George.
Out of two evils he's accounted wise,
That can pick out the least; the fine imposed
For an ungowned senator, is about
Forty cruzadoes, the carpet not 'bove four.
Thus have I chosen the lesser evil yet,
Preserved my patience, foiled her desperate wit.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Here, sir, here's the carpet. Enter George.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: O well done, George, we'll cut it just ith' midst:
'Tis very well I thank thee, help it on.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: It must come over your head, sir, like a wench's petticoat.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Thou'rt in the right, good George, it must indeed.
Fetch me a nightcap: for I'll gird it close,
As if my health were queasy: 'twill show well
For a rude careless nightgown, wil't not thinkst?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Indifferent well, sir, for a nightgown, being girt and pleated.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Ay, and a nightcap on my head.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: That's true sir, I'll run and fetch one, and a staff. Exit Ge.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: For thus they cannot choose but construe it,
One that is out of health, takes no delight,
Wears his apparel without appetite,
And puts on heedless raiment without form. Enter geo.
sp.p: So so, kind George, be secret now: and prithee do not laugh at me till I me out of sight.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I laugh? not I sir.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Now to the senate-house:
Methinks, I'd rather wear, without a frown,
A patient carpet, than an angry gown. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Now looks my m. just like one of our carpet knights, only he's somewhat the honester of the two. Enter Candido's wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: What, is your master gone?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes forsooth, his back is but new turned.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: And in his cloak? did he not vex and swear?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: No, but he'll make you swear anon: no indeed, he went away like a lamb.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Key sink to hell: still patient, patient still!
I am with child to vex him: prithee George,
If ere thou lookest for favour at my hands,
Uphold one jest for me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Against my master?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: 'Tis a mere jest in faith: say, wilt thou do't?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: Well, what is't?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Here, take this key, thou knowest where all things lie,
Put on thy master's best apparel, gown,
Chain, cap, ruff, every thing, be like himself,
And 'gainst his coming home, walk in the shop,
Fain the same carriage, and his patient look,
'Twill breed but a jest thou knowest, speak, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: 'Twill wrong my master's patience.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Prithee George.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Well, if you'll save me harmless, and put me under covert barn, I am content to please you provided it may breed no wrong against him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: No wrong at all: here take the key, be gone:
If any vex him, this: if not this, noneExeunt.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: O Roger, Roger, where's your mistress, where's your mistress? there's the finest, neatest gentleman at my house, but newly come over: oh where is she, where is she, where is she?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: My mistress is abroad, but not amongst 'em: my mistress is not the whore now that you take her for.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: How? is she not a whore? do you go about to take away her good name, Roger? you are a fine pandar indeed.

sp.speaker: Rog.
