sp.p: I tell you ▪ madonna Finger-lock, I am not sad for nothing, I ha' not eaten one good meal this three and thirty days: I had wont to get sixteen pence by fetching a pottle of hippocras: but now those days are past: we had as good doings, madonna Finger-lock, she within doors and I without, as any poor young couple in Milan.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: God's my life, and is she changed now?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I ha' lost by her squeamishness, more than would have builded 12. bawdy houses.

And had she no time to turn honest but now? what a vile woman is this? twenty pound a night, I'll be sworn, Roger, in good gold and no silver: why here was a time, if she should ha' picked out a time, it could not be better! gold enough stirring; choice of men, choice of hair, choice of beards, choice of legs, and choice of every, every, every thing: it cannot sink into my head, that she should be such an ass. Roger, I never believe it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Here she comes now. Enter Bellafronte.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: O sweet madonna, on with your loose gown, your felt and your feather, there's the sweetest, properest, gallantest gentleman at my house, he smells all of musk and amber grease, his pocket full of crowns, flame-coloured doublet, red satin hose, carnation silk stockings, and a leg and a body, o!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hence, thou our sex's monster, poisonous bawd,
Lust's factor, and damnation's orator,
Gossip of hell, were all the harlot's sins
Which the whole world contains, numbered together,
Thine far exceeds them all; of all the creatures
That ever were created, thou art basest:
What serpent would beguile thee of thy office?
It is detestable: for thou liv'st
Upon the dregs of harlots, guard'st the door,
Whilst couples go to dancing: oh course devil!
Thou art the bastard's curse, thou brandest his birth,
The lechers French disease; for thou dry-suck'st him:
The harlot's poison, and thine own confusion.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Marry come up with a pox, have you nobody to rail against, but your bawd now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And you, knave Pandar, kinsman to a bawd.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: You and I madonna, are cozens.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Of the same blood and making, near allied,
Thou, that slave to sixpence, base-metaled villain.

sp.speaker: Rog,
sp.p: Sixpence? nay that's not so; I never took under two shillings four pence, I hope I know my fee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I know not against which most to inveigh:
For both of you are damned so equally.
Thou never sparest for oaths: swearest any thing,
As if thy soul were made of shoe-leather.
God dam me, gentleman, if she be within,
When in the next room she's found dallying.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: If it be my vocation to swear, every man in his vocation: I hope my betters swear and dam themselves, and why should not I?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Roger, you cheat kind gentlemen ▪

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: The more gulls they.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Slave, I cashier thee.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: And you do cashier him, he shall be entertained.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Shall I? then Blurt a your service.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As hell would have it, entertained by you!
I dare the devil himself to match those two. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Mary gup, are you grown so holy, so pure, so honest with a pox?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Scurvy honest punk! But stay madonna, how must our agreement be now? for you know I am to have all the comings in at the hall door, and you at the chamber door.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: True Rog. except my vails.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Vails, what vails?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Why as thus, if a couple come in a coach, and light to lie down a little, than Roger, that's my fee, and you may walk abroad; for the coach man himself is their pandar.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Is a so? in truth I have almost forgotten, for want of exercise: but how if I fetch this citizens wife to that gull, and that madonna to that gallant, how then?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: Why then, Roger, you are to have sixpence a lane, so many lanes, so many sixpences.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Is't so? then I see we two shall agree and live together.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I Roger, so long as there be any taverns and bawdy houses in Milan. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena 9.
div.stage: Enter Bellafronte with a lute, pen, ink and paper being placed before her.
div.l: That suck up poor bees honeys:
Silks and velvets, pearls and ambers,
Shall not draw me to their chambers. She writes.
O, 'tis in vain to write: it will not please,
Ink on this paper would ha' but presented
The foul black spots that stick upon my soul,
And rather make me lothsomer, then wrought
My love's impression in Hipolito's thought.
No, I must turn the chaste leaves of my breast,
And pick out some sweet means to breed my rest.
Hipolito, believe me I will be
As true unto thy heart, as thy heart to thee,
and hate all men, their gifts and company.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You, goody punk, subandi cockatrice, oh you're a sweet whore of your promise, are you not think you? how well you came to supper to us last night: mew, a whore and break her word! nay you may blush, and hold down your head at it well enough: 'sfoot, ask these gallants if we stayed not till we were as hungry as sergeants.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ay, and their yeoman too.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Nay faith acquaintance, let me tell you, you forgot yourself too much: we had excellent cheer, rare vintage, and were drunk after supper.

sp.speaker: Pior.
sp.p: And when we were in our woodcocks (Sweet rogue) a brace of gulls, dwelling here in the city, came in and paid all the shot.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on her, let her alone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O, I pray do, if you be gentlemen:
I pray depart the house; beshrew the door
For being so easily entreated: faith,
I lent but little ear unto your talk,
My mind was busied otherwise in troth,
And so your words did unregarded pass:
Let this suffice, I am not as I was.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: I am not what I was! no I'll be sworn thou art not: for thou wert honest at five, and now thou'rt a punk at fifteen: thou wert yesterday a simple whore, and now thou'rt a cunning coney-catching baggage today.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll say I me worse, I pray forsake me then,
I do desire you leave me, gentlemen,
And leave yourselves: oh be not what you are,
(Spendthrifts of soul and body)
Let me persuade you to forsake all harlots,
Worse than the deadliest poisons, they are worse:
For o'er their souls hangs an eternal curse,
In being slaves to slaves, their labours perish,
They're seldom blessed with fruit; for ere it blossoms,
Many a worm confounds it.
They have no issue but foul ugly ones,
That run along with them, e'en to their graves:
For stead of children, they breed rank diseases,
and all, you gallants, can bestow on them,
Is that French infant, which ne'er acts but speaks:
What shallow son and heir then, foolish gallant,
Would waste all his inheritance, to purchase
A filthy loathed disease? and pawn his body
To a dry evil: that usury's worst of all,
When th'interest will eat out the principal.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, she gulls 'em the best: this is always her fashion, when she would be rid of any company that she cares not for, to enjoy mine alone.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: What's here? instructions, admonitions, and caveats? come out, you scabbard of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Fluello, spurn your hounds when they fist, you shall not spurn my punk, I can tell you my blood is vexed.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Pox a your blood: make it a quarrel.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You're a slave, will that serve turn?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: 'Sblood, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Matheo, Fluello, for shame put up.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Spurn my sweet varlet!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O how many thus
Moved with a little folly, have let out
Their souls in brothel houses, fell down and died
Just at their harlot's foot, as 'twere in pride.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Matheo, we shall meet.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ay, ay, anywhere , saving at church: pray take heed we meet not there.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Adieu, damnation.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Cockatrice, farewell.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: There's more deceit in women, then in hell. Exeunt ▪

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, thou dost gull 'em so rarely, so naturally: if I did not think thou hadst been in earnest: thou art a sweet rogue for't i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why are not you gone to, signior Matheo?
I pray depart my house: you may believe me,
In troth I have no part of harlot in me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Indeed I love you not: but hate you worse
Than any man, because you were the first
gave money for my soul; you broke the ice,
Which after turned a puddle: I was led
By your temptation to be miserable:
I pray seek out some other that will fall,
Or rather (I pray) seek out none at all.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is't possible, to be impossible, an honest whore! I have heard many honest wenches turn strumpets with a wet finger; but for a harlot to turn honest, is one of Hercules' labours: it was more easy for him in one night to make fifty queans, than to make one of them honest again in fifty years: come, I hope thou dost but jest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis time to leave off jesting, I had almost
Jested away salvation: I shall love you,
If you will soon forsake me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: God buy thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O, tempt no more women: shun their weighty curse,
Women (At best) are bad, make them not worse,
You gladly seek our sex's overthrow:
But not to raise our states for all your wrongs.
Will you vouchsafe me but due recompense,
To marry with me?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How, marry with a punk, a cockatrice, a harlot? marry foh, I'll be burned thorough the nose first.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why la? these are your oaths you love to undo us,
To put heaven from us, whilst our best hours waste:
You love to make us lewd, but never chaste.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll hear no more of this: this ground upon,
Thou'rt damned for altering thy religion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy lust and sin speak so much: go thou my ruin,
The first fall my soul took; by my example
I hope few maidens now will put their heads
Under men's girdles: who least trusts, is most wise:
Men's oaths do cast a mist before our eyes.
My best of wit be ready: now I go,
By some device to greet Hipolito.

div.head: Scaena 10.
div.stage: Enter a servant setting out a table, on which be places a scull, a picture, a book and a taper.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: So, this is Monday morning, and now must I to my housewifry: would I had been created a shoemaker; for all the gentle craft are gentlemen every Monday by their copy, and scorn (Then) to work one true stitch. My m. means sure to turn me into a student; for here's my book, here my desk, here my light; this my close chamber, and here my punk: so that this dull drowsy first day of the week, makes me half a priest, half a chandler, half a painter, half a sexton, I and half a bawd: for (All this day) my office is to do nothing but keep the door. To prove it, look you, this good-face and yonder gentleman (So soon as ever my back's turned) will be naught together. Enter Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Are all the windows shut?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Close sir, as the fist of a courtier that hath stood in three reigns.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou art a faithful servant, and observest
The calendar, both of my solemn vows,
And ceremonious sorrow: get thee gone,
I charge thee on thy life, let not the sound
Of any woman's voice pierce through that door.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: If they do, my lord, I'll pierce some of them.
What will your lordship have to breakfast?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Sighs.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: What to dinner?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Tears.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The one of them, my lord, will fill you too full of wind, the other wet you too much. What to supper?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: That which (Now) thou canst not get me, the constancy of a woman.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Indeed that's harder to come by then ever was Ostend.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Prithee away.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I'll make away myself presently, which few servants will do for their lords; but rather help to make them away: now to my doorkeeping, I hope to pick something out of it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My Infaelice's face: her brow, her eye,
The dimple on her cheek: and such sweet skill,
hath from the cunning workman's pencil flown,
These lips look fresh and lively as her own,
Seeming to move and speak. 'las I now I see,
The reason why fond women love to buy
Adulterate complexion: here 'tis read,
False colours last after the true be dead.
Of all the roses grafted on her cheeks,
Of all the graces dancing in her eyes,
Of all the music set upon her tongue,
Of all that was passed woman's excellence,
In her white bosom, look! A painted board,
Circumscribes all: earth can no bliss afford.
Nothing of her, but this? this cannot speak,
It has no lap for me to rest upon,
No lip worth tasting: here the worms will feed,
As in her coffin: hence then idle art,
True love's best pictured in a truelove's heart.
Here art thou drawn sweet maid, till this be dead,
So that thou liv'st twice, twice art buried.
Thou figure of my friend, lie there. What's here?
Perhaps this shrewd pate was mine enemies:
'Las! say it were: I need not fear him now:
For all his braves, his contumelious breath,
His frowns (Though dagger-pointed) all his plot,
(Tho' ne'er so mischievous) his Italian pills,
His quarrels, and (That common fence) his law,
See, see, they're all eaten out; here's not left one?
How clean they're picked away! to the bare bone!
How mad are mortals then to rear great names
On tops of swelling houses? or to wear out
Their fingers ends (In dirt,) to scrape up gold!
Not caring so (That sumpter-horse) the back
Be hung with gawdy trappings, with what course,
Yea rags most beggarly, they clothe the soul:
Yet (After all) their gayness looks thus foul.
What fools are men to build a garish tomb,
Only to save the carcase whilst it rots,
To maintein't long in stinking, make good carrion,
but leave no good deeds to preserve them sound,
For good deeds keep men sweet, long above ground,
And must all come to this; fools; wise, all hither,
Must all heads thus at last be laid together:
Draw me my picture then, thou grave neat workman,
After this fashion, not like this; these colours
In time kissing but air, will be kissed off,
But here's a fellow; that which he lays on,
Till doom's day, alters not complexion.
Death's' the best painter then: they that draw shapes,
And live by wicked faces, are but god's apes,
They come but near the life, and there they stay,
This fellow draws life to: his art is fuller,
The pictures which he makes are without colour.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here's a person would speak with you sir.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: A parson sir would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Vicar?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Vicar? no sir, has too good a face to be a vicar yet, a youth, a very youth.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What youth? of man or woman? lock the doors.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: If it be a woman, marrowbones and potato pies keep me for meddling with her, for the thing has got the breeches, 'tis a male-varlet sure my lord, for a woman's tailor ne'er measured him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Let him give thee his message and be gone.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: He says he's signior Matheo's man, but I know he lies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How dost thou know it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: 'Cause has ne'er a beard: 'tis his boy I think sir, whosoe'er paid for his nursing.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Send him and keep the door. Reads.
Fata si liceat mihi,
Fingere arbitrio meo,
Temperem zephyro levivela.
I'd sail were I to choose, not in the ocean,
cedars are shaken, when shrubs do feel no bruise ▪
How? from Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Art sick?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not all in health my lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Keep off.

sp.speaker: Belle.
sp.l: I do:
Hard fate when women are compelled to woo.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This paper does speak nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Yes my lord,
Matter of life it speaks, and therefore writ
In hidden character; to me instruction
My master gives, and (Less you please to stay
Till you both meet) I can the text display.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Do so: read out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am already out:
Look on my face, and read the strangest story!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What villain, ho? Enter his servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Call you my lord?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou slave, thou hast let in the devil.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Lord bless us, where? he's not cloven my lord that I can see: besides the devil goes more like a gentleman than a page: good my lord boon couragio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Thou hast let in a woman in man's shape.
And thou art damned for't.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Not damned I hope for putting in a woman to a lord.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Fetch me my rapier, — do not: I shall kill thee.
Purge this infected chamber of that plague,
That runs upon me thus: slave, thrust her hence.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Alas my lord, I shall never be able to thrust her hence without help: come mermaid you must to sea again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Hear me but speak, my words shall be all music:
Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Another beats the door,
Tother she-devil, look.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Why then hell's broke loose. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Hence, guard the chamber: let no more come on,
one woman serves for man's damnation.
Beshrew thee, thou dost make me violate,
The chastest and most sanctimonious vow,
That ere was entered in the court of heaven:
I was on meditations spotless wings,
Upon my journey thither; like a storm
Thou beats my ripened cogitations,
Flat to the ground: and like a thief dost stand,
To steal devotion from the holy land.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If woman were thy mother; if thy heart,
Be not all marble, (Or if't marble be)
Let my tears soften it, to pity me,
I do beseech the do not thus with scorn,
Destroy a woman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Woman I beseech thee,
Get thee some other suit, this fits thee not,
I would not grant it to a kneeling Queen,
I cannot love thee, nor I must not: see,
The copy of that obligation,
Where my soul's bound in heavy penalties.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She's dead you told me, she'll let fall her suit.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: My vows to her, fled after her to heaven,
Were thine eyes clear as mine, thou mightst behold her,
Watching upon yond battlements of stars,
How I observe them: should I break my bond,
This board would rive in twain, these wooden lips
Call me most perjured villain, let it suffice,
I ha' set thee in the path; is't not a sign,
I love thee, when with one so most most dear,
I'll have thee fellows? All are fellows there.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be greater than a King, save not a body,
But from eternal shipwreck keep a soul,
If not, and that again, sin's path I tread,
The grief be mine, the guilt fall on thy head.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Stay and take physic for it, read this book,
Ask counsel of this head what's to be done,
He'll strike it dead that 'tis damnation,
If you turn Turk again, o do it not,
the heaven cannot allure you to do well
From doing ill let hell fright you: and learn this,
The soul whose bosom lust did never touch,
Is god's fair bride, and maiden's souls are such:
The soul that leaving chastities white shore,
Swims in hot sensual streams, is the devil's whore,
How now: who comes. Enter his servant.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: No more knaves my lord that wear smocks: here's a letter from doctor Benedict; I would not enter his man, though he had hairs at his mouth, for fear he should be a woman, for some women have beards, marry they are half witches, slid you are a sweet youth to wear a codpiece, and have no pins to stick upon't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll meet the doctor, tell him, yet tonight
I cannot: but at morrow rising sun
I will not fail: go: woman fare thee well. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lowest fall can be but into hell,
It does not move him. I must therefore fly,
From this undoing city, and with tears,
Wash off all anger from my father's brow,
He cannot sure but joy seeing me new born,
A woman honest first and then turn whore,
Is (As with me) common to thousands more,
But from a strumpet to turn chaste: that sound,
Has oft been heard, that woman hardly found. Exit.

div.head: 11. Sce.

sp.speaker: Fus.
sp.p: Hold up your hands gentlemen: here's one, two, three, (Nay I warrant they are sound pistols, and without flaws, I had them (Of my sister, and I know she uses to put nothing that's cracked,) three, four, five, six, seven, eight and nine, by this hand bring me but a piece of his blood. and you shall have 9. more. I'll lurk in a tavern not far off, and provide supper to close up the end of the tragedy, the linen drapers remēber-stand toot I beseech you, and play your parts perfectly.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Look you signior, 'tis not your gold that we way.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.l: Nay, nay, way it and spare not, if it lack one grain of corn;
I'll give you a bushel of wheat to make it up.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p:
But by your favour signior, which of the servants
is it, because we'll punish justly.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Marry 'tis the head man; you shall razed him by his tongue a pretty tall prating fellow, with a tuscalonian beard.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Tuscalonian: very good.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Cod's life I was ne'er so thrummed since I was a gentleman: my coxcomb was dry beaten as if my hair had been hemp.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: We'll dry beat some of them.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nay it grew so high, that my sister cried murder out very manfully: I have her consent in a manner to have him peppered, else I'll not do't to win more than ten cheaters do at a rifling: break but his pate or so, only his mazer, because I'll have his head in a cloth as well as mine, he's a linen draper and may take enough. I could enter mine action of battery against him, but we may haps be both dead and rotten before the lawyers would end it.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No more to do, but ensconce yourself i'th tavern; provide no great cheat, couple of capons, some pheasants, plovers, an oringeado-pie or so: but how bloody soe'er the day be, sally you not forth.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: No, no, nay if I stir, somebody shall stink: I'll not budge: I'll lie like a dog in a manger.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Well, well, to the tavern, let not our supper be raw, for you shall have blood enough-your belly full.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: That's all so god same, I thirst after, blood for blood, bump for bump, nose for nose, head for head, plaster for plaster, and so farewell: what shall I call your names because I'll leave word, if any such come to the bar.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: My name is corporal Crambo.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: And mine, lieutenant Poh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Poli. Is as tall a man as ever opened oyster: I would not be the devil to meet poh, farewell.

sp.speaker: Fust.
sp.p: Nor I by this light, if Poh be such a Poh. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Condido's wife, in her shop, and the two premises.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What's o'clock now.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: 'Tis almost 12.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That's well.
The senate will leave wording presently:
But is George ready,

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, he's surbusht.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now as you ever hope to win my favour,
Throw both your duties and respects on him,
With the like awe as if he were your master,
Let not your looks betray it with a smile,
Or jeering glance to any customer,
Keep a true settled countenance, and beware,
You laugh not whatsoever you hear or see.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: I warrant you mistress, let us alone for keeping our countenance: for if I list, there's never a fool in all Milan shall make me laugh, let him play the fool never so like an ass, whether it be the fat court fool, or the lean city fool.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Enough then, call down George.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.l: I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Be ready with your legs then let me see,
How curtsy would become him: gallantly!
Beshrew my blood a proper seemly man,
Of a choice carriage walks with a good port,

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I thank you mistress, my back's broad enough, now my master's gown's on.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sure I should think it were the least of sin,
To mistake the master, and to let him in.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Twere a good comedy of errors that i'faith.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.p: Whist, whist, my master.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: You all know your tasks: gods my life, what's that he has got upon's back? who can tell?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: That can I, but I will not.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Girt about him like a madman: what: has he lost his cloak too: this is the maddest fashion that ere I saw.

lg.l: What said he George when he paced by thee?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Troth mistress nothing: not so much as a bee, he did not hum: not so much as a bawd he did not hem: not so much as a cuckold he did not ha': neither hum, hem, nor ha, only stared me in the face, passed along, and made haste in, as if my looks had worked with him, to give him a stool.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Sure he's vexed now, this trick has moved his spleen,
He's angered now, because he uttered nothing:
And wordless wrath breaks out more violent,
May be he'll strive for place, when he comes down,
But if thou lovest me George, afford him none.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay let me alone to play my master's prize, as long as my mistress warrants me: I'm sure I have his best clothes on, and I scorn to give place to any that is inferior in apparel to me, that's an axiom, a principle, and is observed as much as the fashion; let that persuade you then, that lie shoulder with him for the upper hand in the shop, as long as this chain will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Spoken with the spirit of a master, though with the tongue of a prentice.
Why how now madman? what in your tricksicoates!

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: O peace good mistress:Enter Crambo and Poli.see what you lack, what is't you buy? pure calicoes, fine hollands, choice cambrics, neat lawns: see what you buy? pray come near, my master will use you well, he can afford you a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I that he can, out of a whole piece of lawn i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Pray see your choice here gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O fine fool? what a madman? A patient madman? whoever heard of the like? well sir I'll fit you and your humour presently: what? cross-points, I'll untie 'em all in a trice, I'll vex you faith: boy take your cloak, quick, come. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Be covered George, this chain, and welted gown, bore to this coat: then the world's upside down ▪

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Umh, umh, hum.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: That's the shop, and there's the fellow.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.p: I but the master is walking in there.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: No matter, we'll in.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: 'Sblood dost long to lie in limbo?

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: And limbo be in hell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Look you gentlemen, your choice: cambrics?

sp.speaker: Cramb.
sp.p: No sir, some shirting.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Have you none of this striped canvas for doublets.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: None striped sir, but plain.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: I think there be one piece striped within.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Step sirrah and fetch it, hum, hum hum.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Look you gentlemen, I'll make but one spreading, here's a piece of cloth, fine, yet shall wear like iron, 'tis without fault, take this upon my word, 'tis without fault.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Then 'tis better than you sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Ay, and a number more, o that each soul
Were but as spotless as this innocent white,
And had as few brakes in it.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: 'Twould have some then: there was a fray here last day in this shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: There was indeed a little flea-biting.

sp.speaker: Poh.
sp.p: A gentleman had his pate broke, call you that but a flea-biting.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: He had so.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: Zounds do you stand in't? He strikes him.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: 'Sfoot clubs, clubs, prentices, down with 'em, ah you rogues, strike a citizen in's shop.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: None of you stir I pray, forbear good George.

sp.speaker: Cram.
sp.p: I beseech you sir, we mistook our marks, delivers us our weapons.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your head bleeds sir, cry clubs.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: I say you shall not, pray be patient,
Give them their weapons, sirs you're best be gone,
I tell you here are boys more tough than bears:
Hence, lest more fists do walk about your ears.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We thank you sir. Exeunt,

sp.speaker: Gan.
sp.l: You shall not follow them.
Let them alone pray, this did me no harm,
Troth I was cold, and the blow made me warm,
I thank 'em for't: besides I had decreed
To have a vain pricked, I did mean to bleed,
So that there's money saved: they are honest men,
Pray use 'em well, when they appear again.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes sir, we'll use 'em like honest men.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I well said George, like honest men, though they be arrant knaves, for that's the praise of the city; help to lay up these wares

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yonder he stands.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: What in a prentice-coat?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Ay, ay, mad, mad, pray take heed.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: How now? what news with them? what make they with my wife? officers is she attached? look to your wares.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: He talks to himself, o he's much gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Pray pluck up a good heart, be not so fearful,
Sirs hark, we'll gather to him by degrees.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Ay, ay, by degrees I pray: o me! what makes he with the lawn in his hand, he'll tear all the ware in my shop.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Fear not we'll catch him on a sudden.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O you had needs do so, pray take heed of your warrant

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: I warrant mistress. — now signior Candido?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Now sir, what news with you sir?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: What news with you he says: o he's far gone.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: I pray fear nothing, let's alone with him,
Signior, you look not like yourself methinks ,
(Steal you a tother side) you're changed, you're altered.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Changed sir, why true sir, is change strange, 'tis not the fashion unless it alter: monarchs turn to beggars; beggars creep into the nests of princes, masters serve their prentices: ladies their serving-men, men turn to women.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: And women turn to men.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Ay, and women turn to men, you say true, ha ha, a mad world, a mad world.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: Have we caught you sir?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Caught me: well, well: you have caught: me.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: He laughs in your faces.

sp.speaker: Geo
sp.p: A rescue prentices, my master's catchpole.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: I charge you keep the peace, or have your legs gartered with irons, we have from the Duke a warrant strong enough for what we do.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I pray rest quiet, I desire no rescue.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: La: he desires no rescue, I as poor heart,
He talks against himself.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Well, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Look to that arm,
Pray make sure work, double the cord.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Why, why?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Look how his head goes! should he get but lose,
O 'twere as much as all our lives were worth.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Fear not, we'll make all sure for our own safety.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Are you at leisure now? well, what's the matter?
Why do I enter into bonds thus? ha?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Because you're mad, put fear upon your wife.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O ay, I went in danger of my life, every minute.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: What? am I mad say you, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: That proves you mad, because you know it not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Pray talk as little to him as you can,
You see he's too far spent.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Bound with strong cord,
A sister's thread i'faith had been enough,
To lead me anywhere : wife do you long?
You are mad too, or else you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: But are you mad indeed master?

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: My wife says so,
And what she says; George, is all truth you know:
And whether now? to Bethlem monastery? — ha! whether?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Faith e'en to the madmen's pound.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: A god's name, still I feel my patience sound. Exe.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come we'll see whether he goes, if the master be mad, we are his servants, and must follow his steps, we'll be mad caps too; farewell mistress, you shall have us all in bedlam. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I think, I ha' fitted now, you and your clothes,
If this move not his patience, nothing can,
I'll swear then I have a saint, and not a manExit.

div.head: 13. Sce.
div.stage: Enter Duke: doctor: Fluello, Castruchio, Pioratto.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Give us a little leave. Doctor your news.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I sent for him my lord: at last he came,
And did receive all speech that went from me,
As gilded pills made to prolong his health:
My credit with him wrought it: for, some men.
Swallow even empty hooks, like fools. that fear
No drowning where 'tis deepest, cause 'tis clear:
In th'end we sat and eat: a health I drank
To Infaelice's sweet departed soul,
(This train I knew would take.)

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Twas excellent.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He fell with such devotion on his knees,
To pledge the same.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Fond superstitious fool?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: That had he been inflamed with zeal of prayer,
He could not power't out with more reverence.
About my neck he hung, wept on my cheek,
Kissed it, and swore, he would adore my lips,
Because they brought forth Infaelice's name.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ha, ha, alack, alack.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: The cup he lifts up high, and thus he said,
Here noble maid: drinks, and was poisoned.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And died?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And died my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou in that word,
Hast pieced mine aged hours out with more years,
Than thou hast taken from Hipolito,
A noble youth he was, but lesser branches
Hindering the greater's growth, must be lopped off,
And feed the fire: doctor we're now all thine,
And use us so: be bold.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Thanks gracious lord:
My honoured lord:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Hmh.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I do beseech your grace to bury deep,
This bloody act of mine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay, nay, for that,
Doctor look you to't: me it shall not move,
Their cursed that ill do, not that ill do love,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You throw an angry forehead on my face,
But be you pleased, backward thus for to look,
That for your good, this evil I undertook,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ay, ay, we construe so:

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And only for your love.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Confessed: 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nor let it stand against me as a bar,
To thrust me from your presence: nor believe
(As princes have quick thoughts,) that now my finger
Being dipped in blood, I will not spare the hand,
But that for gold (As what can gold not do?)
I may be hired to work the like on you,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Which to prevent.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: 'Tis from my heart as far.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No matter doctor, cause I'll fearless sleep,
And that you shall stand clear of that suspicion
I banish thee for ever from my court.
This principle is old but true as fate,
Kings may love treason, but the traitor hate,Exit.

sp.speaker: Do●..
sp.l: Is't so: nay then Duke, your stale principle
With one as stale, the doctor thus shall quit,
He falls himself that digs another's pit,
How now: where is he? will he meet me:

sp.speaker: Doctor man,
sp.p: Meet you sir, he might have met with three fencers in this time and have received less hurt than by meeting one doctor of physic: why sir has walked under the old abbey wall yonder this hour, till he's more cold than a citizen's country house in january, you may smell him behind sir; la you: yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Leave me. Enter Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Doctor man.
sp.l: Itch lurch if you will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: O my most noble friend.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Few but yourself,
Could have intied me thus, to trust the air,
With my close sighs, you send for me: what news?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Come you must doff this black: die that pale cheek,
Into his own colour; go: attire yourself
Fresh as a bridegroom, when he meets his bride,
The Duke has done much treason to thy love,
'Tis now revealed, 'tis now to be revenged,
Be merry honoured friend, thy lady lives.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What lady?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Infaelice, she's revived;
Revived: alack! death never had the heart,
To take breath from her.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Umh: I thank you sir,
Physic prolongs life, when it cannot save,
This helps not my hopes. mine are in their grave:
You do some wrong to mock me.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: By that love,
Which I have ever born you, what I speak
Is truth: the maiden lives: that funeral,
Duke's tears, the morning, was all counterfeit,
A sleepy draught cozened the world and you,
I was his minister and then chambered up,
To stop discovery.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O treacherous Duke:

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: He cannot hope so certainly for bliss:
As he believes that I have poisoned you,
He wooed me to't, I yielded, and confirmed him,
In his most bloody thoughts.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: A very devil!

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Her did he closely coach to Bergamo,
And thither?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Will I ride, stood Bergamo,
In the low countries of black hell, I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You shall to her, but not to Bergamo,
How passion makes you fly beyond yourself.
Much of that weary journey I ha' cut off,
For she by letters hath intelligence,
of your supposed death, her own interment,
And all those plots, which that false Duke, (Her father)
Has wrought against you: and she'll meet you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O when:

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay see: how covetous are your desires,
Easely tomorrow morn.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O where good father.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: At Bethlem monastery: are you pleased now?

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.l: At Bethlem monastery: the place well fits,
It is the school where those that lose their wits,
Practice again to get them: I am sick
Of that disease, all love is lunatic.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We'll steal away, this night in some disguise,
Father Anselmo, a most reverend friar,
Expects our coming, before whom we'll lay,
Reasons so strong, that he shall yield, in bonds,
O holy wedlock, to tie both your hands.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: This is such happiness:
That to believe it ▪ 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Let all your joys then die in misbelief,
I will reveal no more.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O yes good father,
I am so well acquainted with despair,
I know not how to hope: I believe all.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: We'll hence this night, much must be done, much said
But if the doctor fail not in his charms,
Your lady shall ere morning fill these arms.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Heavenly physician: far thy fame shall spread,
That mak'st two lovers speak when they be dead.

div.stage: Candido's wife, and George: Pioratto meets them.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O watch good George, watch which way the Duke comes.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here comes one of the butter flies, ask him.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Pray sir, comes the Duke this way.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: He's upon coming mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I thank you sir: George are there many mad-folks, where thy master lies.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: O yes, of all countries some, but especially mad Greeks they swarm: troth mistress, the world is altered with you, you had not wont to stand thus with a paper humbly complaining: but you're well enough served: provender pricked you, as it does many of our city-wives besides.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Dost think George we shall get him forth.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Truly mistress I cannot tell, I think you'll hardly get him forth: why 'tis strange ▪ 'sfoot I have known many women that have had mad rascals to their husbands, whom they would belabour by all means possible to keep 'em in their right wits, but of a woman too long to turn a tame man into a madman, why the devil himself was never used so by his dam.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How does he talk George! ha! good George tell me.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Why your best go see.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Alas I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Afraid! you had more need be ashamed: he may rather be afraid of you.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: But George he's not stark mad, is he? he does not rave, he's not horn-mad George is he?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Nay I know not that, but he talks like a justice of peace, of a thousand matters and to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I'll to the monastery: I shall be mad till I enjoy him, I shall be sick till I see him, yet when I do see him, I shall weep out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Ay, I'd fain see a woman weep out her eyes; that's as true, as to say, a man's cloak burns; when it hangs in the water: I know you'll weep mistress, but what says the painted cloth.

lg.l: Trust not a woman when she cries,
For she'll pump water from her eyes,
With a wet finger, and in faster showers,
Than April when he rains down flowers.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I but George, that painted cloth is worthy to be hanged up for lying, all women have not tears at will, unless they have good cause.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I but mistress how easily will they find a cause, and as one of our cheese-trenchers says very learnedly:

lg.l: As out of wormwood bees suck honey,
As from poor clients lawyers firk money,
as parsley from a roasted coney.
So though the day be ne'er so sunny,
If wives will have it rain, down then it drives,
The calmest husbands make the stormest wives,

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Tame George, but I had on storming now.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Why that's well done, good mistress throw aside this fashion of your humour, be not so fantastical in wearing it, storm no more, long no more. — this longing has made you come short of many a good thing that you might have had from my master: here comes the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O I beseech you pardon my offence,
In that I durst abuse your graces warrant,
Deliver forth my husband good my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who is her husband?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Candido my lord,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: He's among the lunatics,
He was a man made up without a gall,
Nothing could move him, nothing could convert
His meek blood into fury, yet like a monster,
I often beat at the most constant rock
Of his unshaken patience, and did long
To vex him.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Did you so?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And for that purpose,
Had warrant from your grace, to carry him
To Bethlem monastery, whence they will not free him,
Without your grace's hand that sent him in.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You have longed fair; 'tis you are mad I fear,
It's fit to fetch him thence, and keep you there:
If he be mad ▪ why would you have him forth?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: And please your grace, he's not stark mad, but only talks like a young gentleman, somewhat fantastically, that's all: there's a thousand about your court, city and country madder than he.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Provide a warrant, you shall have our hand.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here's a warrant ready drawn my lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Get pen and ink, get pen and ink:Enter Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Cast
sp.p: Where is my lord the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How now? more mad men.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I have strange news my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Of what? of whom?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Of Infaelice, and a marriage.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Ha! where? with whom.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Hipolito.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Hence with that woman, void the room.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Away, the duke's vexed.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Whoop, come mistress the duke's mad too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who told me that Hipolito was dead?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He that can make any man dead, the doctor: but my lord, he's as full of life as wildfire, and as quick: Hipolito, the doctor, and one more rid hence this evening; the inn at which they light is Bethlem monastery: Infaeliche comes from Bergamo, and meets them there: Hipolito is mad, for he means this day to be married, the afternoon is the hour, and friar Anselmo is the knitter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: From Bergamo? is't possible? it cannot be,
It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will not swear my lord,
But this intelligence I took from one,
Whose brains works in the plot.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Mathaeo knows all.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: He's Hipolito's bosom.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How far stands Bethlem hence?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Six or seven miles.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is't even so, not married till the afternoon you say?
Stay, stay, let's work out some prevention: how:
This is most strange, can none but madmen serve
To dress their wedding dinner? All of you,
Get presently to horse; disguise yourselves
Like country-gentlemen,
Or riding citizens, or so: and take
Each man a several path, but let us meet,
At Bethlem monastery, some space of time
Being spent between the arrival each of other,
As if we came to see the lunatics.
To horse, away, be secret on your lives,
Love must be punished that unjustly thrives. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Be secret on your lives! Castruchio
you're but a scurvy spaniel; honest lord,
Good lady: zounds their love is just, 'tis good,
And I'll prevent you, though I swim in blood. Exit.

div.stage: Enter friar Anselmo, Hipolito, Mathaeo, Infaeliche.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Nay, nay, resolve good father, or deny.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You press me to an act, both full of danger,
And full of happiness, for I behold.
Your father's frowns, his threats, nay perhaps death,
To him that dare do this, yet noble lord,
Such comfortable beams break through these clouds,
By this blessed marriage, that your honoured word
Being pawned in my defence) I will tie fast,
The holy wedding knot.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tush fear not the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O son, wisely to fear: is to be free from fear.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You have our words, and you shall have our lives,
To guard you safe from all ensuing danger.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ay, ay, chop 'em up and away.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Stay, when is't fit for me, safest for you,
To entertain this business.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Not till the evening.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Be't so, there is a chapel stands hard by,
Upon the West end of the abbey wall,
Thither convey yourselves, and when the sun
Hath turned his back upon this upper world,
I'll marry you, that done, no thundring voice,
Can break the sacred bond, yet lady here you are most safe.

sp.speaker: Infae.
sp.l: Father your love's most dear.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I well said lock us into some little room by ourselves that we may be mad for an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O good Mathaeo no, let's make no noise.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
How! no noise! do you know where you are: 'sfoot amongst all the madcaps in Milan: so that to throw the house out at window will be the better, and no man will suspect that we lurk here to steal mutton: the more sober we are, the more scurvy 'tis. And though the friar tell us, that here we are safest, I'm not of his mind, for if those lay here that had lost there money, none would ever look after them, but hear are none but those that have lost their wits, oh that if hue and cry be made, hither they'll come, and my reason is, because none
goes to be married till he be stark mad.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Muffle yourselves yonder's Fluello. Enter Fluello.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Zounds!

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: O my lord these cloaks are not for this rain, the tempest is too great: I come sweating to tell you of it, that you may get out of it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: What's the matter! you have mattered it fair: the duke's at hand.

sp.speaker: Onm.
sp.l: The Duke?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: The very Duke.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Then all our plots are turned upon our heads; and we are blown up with our own underminings. 'sfoot how comes he, what villain durst betray our being here.

sp.speaker: Flu:
sp.p: Castruchio, Castruchio told the Duke, and Mathaeo here told Castruchio.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would you betray me to Castruchio,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: 'Sfoot he damned himself to the pit of hell if he spoke on't again.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: So did you swear to me, so were you damned.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Pox on 'em, and there be no faith in men, if a man shall not believe oaths: he took bread and salt by this light, that he would never open his lips.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O God, o God.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Son be not desperate have patience, you shall trip your enemy down, by his own slights, how far is the Duke hence.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: He's but new set out: Castruchio, Pioratto and Sinezi come along with him: you have time enough yet to prevent them if you have but courage.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You shall steal secretly into the chapel,
And presently be married; if the Duke
Abide here still, spite of ten thousand eyes,
You shall scape hence like friars.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O blessed disguised: oh happy man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Talk not of happiness till your closed hand,
Have her byth' forehead, like the lock of time,
Be not too slow, nor hasty, now you climb,
Up to the tower of bliss, only be wary
And patient, that's all, if you like my plot
Build and dispatch, if not farewell, than not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O yes, we do applaud it, we'll dispute,
No longer, but will hence and execute.
Fluello you'll stay here, let us be gone,
The ground that freighted lovers tread upon,
Is stuck with thorns.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Come then, away: 'tis meet,
To escape those thorns, to put on winged feet. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No words I pray Fluello, for it stands us upon.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: O sir, let that be your lesson.
Alas poor lovers, on what hopes and fears,
Men toss themselves for women. when she's got
The best has in her that which pleaseth not.

div.stage: Enter to Fluello, the Duke, Castruchio, Pioratto and Sinezi from several doors muffled.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Who's there!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Peace, send that lord away,
A lordship will spoil all, let's be all fellows.
What's he.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Fluello, or else Sinezi by his little legs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What! met upon the very point of time,
Is this the place.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: This is the place my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dream you on lordships! come no more lords: pray
You have not seen these lovers yet.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Castruchio art thou sure this wedding feat,
Is not till afternoon?

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.l: So 'tis given out my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay, nay, 'tis like, thieves must observe their hours,
Lovers watch minutes like astronomers,
How shall the interim hours by us be spent,

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Let's all go see the madmen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Mas content. Enter town like a sweeper.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O here comes one, question him, question him.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: How now honest fellow dost thou belong to the house.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I am one of the implements; I sweep the madmen's rooms, and fetch straw for 'em, and buy chains to tie 'em, and rods to whip 'em, I was a mad wag myself here once, but I thank father Anselm he lashed me into my right mind again.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Anselmo is the friar must marry them,
Question him where he is,

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: And where is father Anselmo now?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Marry he's gone but e'en now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Ay, well done, tell me, whether is he gone?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Why to God a mighty.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this fellow is a fool, talks idly.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Sirrah are all the mad folks in Milan brought hither?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: How all, there's a wise question indeed: why if all the mad folks in Milan should come hither, there would not be left ten men in the city.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Few gentlemen or courtiers here, ha.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: O yes? abundance, abundance, lands no sooner fall into their hands, but straight they run out a their wits: citizens sons and heirs are free of the house by their father's copy: farmers' sons come hither like geese (In flocks) and when they ha' sold all their corn fields, here they sit and pick the straws.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: methinks you should have women here as well as men.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: O, I: a plague on 'em, there's no ho with them, they are madder than march hairs.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Are there no lawyers here amongst you?

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: O no, not one: never any lawyer, we dare not let a lawyer come in, for he'll make 'em mad faster than we can recover 'em.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And how long is't ere you recover any of these.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Why according to the quantity of the moon that's got into 'em, an alderman's son will be mad a great while a very great while, especially if his friends left him well, a whore will hardly come to her wits again: a Puritan there's no hope of him, unless he may pull down the steeple and hang himself it'h bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: I perceive all sorts of fish come to your net.

sp.speaker: Tow.
sp.p: Yes intruth, we have blocks for all heads, we have good store of wild oats here: for the courtier is mad at the citizen, the citizen is mad at the country men, the shoemaker is mad at the cobbler, the cobbler at the carman the punk is mad that the merchant's wife is no whore, the merchant's wife is mad that the punk is so common a whore: gods so, here's father Anselmo. pray say nothing that I tell tales out of the school. Exit.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God bless you father. Enter Anselmo.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Thank you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pray may we see some of those wretched souls,
That here are in your keeping?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yes: you shall,
But gentlemen I must disarm you then,
There are of mad men, as there are of tame,
All humoured not alike: we have here some,
So apish and fantastic, play with a feather,
And though 'twould grieve a soul, to see God's image,
So blemished and defaced, yet do they act
Such antic and such pretty lunacies,
That spite of sorrow they will make you smile:
Others again we have like hungry lions,
Fierce as wild bulls, untameable as flies,
And these have oftentimes from stranger's sides
Snatched rapiers suddenly, and done much harm,
Whom if you'll see, you must be weaponless.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Here: take these weapons in,
Stand of a little prey, so, so, 'tis well:
I'll show you here a man that was sometimes,
A very grave and wealthy citizen,
Has served a prenticeship to this misfortune,
Been here seven years, and dwelled in Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How fell he from his wits?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: By loss at sea:
I'll stand aside, question him you alone,
For if he spy me, he'll not speak a word,
Unless he's thoroughly vexed. Discovers an old man, wrapped in a Net.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: Alas poor soul.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: A very old man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: God speed father.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: God speed the plough: thou shalt not speed me.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: We see you old man, for all you dance in a net.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: True, but thou wilt dance in a halter, and I shall not see thee.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O, do not vex him pray.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Are you a fisherman father?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.l: No, I'm neither fish nor flesh.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: What do you with that net then?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p:
Dost not see fool! there's a fresh salmon in't: if you step one foot further, you'll be over shoes, for you see I'm
over head and ear in the salt-water: and if you fall into this whirlpool where I am, you're drowned: you're a drownd rat. — I am fishing here for five ships, but I cannot have a good draught, for my net breaks still, and breaks, but I'll break some of your necks and I catch you in my clutches. Stay, stay, stay, stay — where's the wind, where's the wind, where's the wind: where's the wind: out you gulls, you goose-caps, you gudgeon eaters! do you look for the wind in the heavens? ha ha ha ha, no no, look there, look there, look there, the wind is always at that door: hark how it blows, pooff pooff, pooff.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Do you laugh at God's creatures? do you mock old age you rogues? is this grey beard and head counterfeit, that you cry ha ha ha? — sirrah, art not thou my eldest son?

sp.speaker: Pior.
sp.p: Yes indeed father.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Then thou'rt a fool, for my eldest son had a polt foot, crooked legs, a vergis face, and a pear-coloured beard; I made him a scholar, and he made himself a fool. — sirrah! thou there? hold out thy hand.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: My hand, well, here 'tis.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Look, look, look, look: has he not long nails, and short hair?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Yes monstrous short hair, and abominable long nails.

sp.speaker: 1. Ma.
sp.p: Tenpenny nails are they not?

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Yes ten penny nails.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Such nails had my second boy: kneel down thou varlet, and ask thy father blessing. Such nails had my middlemost son and I made him a promoter: and he scrapped, and scrapped, and scrapped, till he got the devil and all: but he scrapped thus and thus, and thus, and it went under his legs, till at length a company of kites taking him for carrion, swept up all, all, all all, all, all, all. — if you love your lives, look to yourselves, see, see, see, see, the Turks galleys are fighting with my ships, bounce goes the guns. — oooh! cry the men: romble romble go the waters — alas! there! 'tis sunk — 'tis sunk: I am undone, I am undone, you are the damned pirates have undone me, — you are byth' lord, you are, you are, stop 'em, you are.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Why how now sirrah, must I fall to tame you?

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Tame me? no: I'll be madder than a roasted cat: see, see, I am burned with gunpowder, these are our close fights.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: I'll whip you, if you grow unruly thus.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Whip me? out you toad: — whip me? what justice is this, to whip me because I'm a beggar? — alas? I am a poor man: a very poor man: I am starved, and have had no meat by this light, ever since the great flood, I am a poor man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Well, well; be quiet and you shall have meat.

sp.speaker: 1. Mad.
sp.p: Ay, ay, pray do, for look you, here be my guts: these are my ribs, — you may look through my ribs, — see how my guts come out — these are my red guts, my very guts, o, o!

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.p: Take him in there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: A very piteous sight.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Father I see you have a busy charge.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: They must be used like children, pleased with toys,
And anon whipped for their unruliness:
I'll show you now a pair quite different
From him that's gone; he was all words: and these
Unless you urge 'em, seldom spend their speech,
But save their tongues la— you this hithermost
Fell from the happy quietness of mind,
About a maiden that he loud, and died:
He followed her to church, being full of tears,
And as her body went into the ground,
He fell stark mad. That is a maryed man,
Was jealous of a fair, but (As some say)
A very virtuous wife, and that spoilt him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: All these are whoremongers and lay with my wife: whore, whore, whore, whore, whore.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: Observe him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p:
Gaffer shoemaker, you pulled on my wife's pumps, and then crept into her pantofles: lie there, lie there, — this was her tailor, - you cut out her loose-bodied gown, and put in a yard more than I allowed her, lie there by the shoemaker: o, master doctor! are you here: you gave me a purgation, and then crept into my wife's chamber, to feel her pulses, and you said, and she said, and her maid said, that they went pit a pat-pit a pat-pit a pat, - doctor I'll put you anon into my wife's urinal: - heigh, come a loft Jack? this was her schoolmaster, and taught her to play upon the virginals, and still his jacks leapt up, up: you pricked her out nothing but bawdy
lessons, but I'll prick you all, - fidler-doctor-tayler-shoomaker, - shoomaker-fidler-doctor-tayler-so! lie with my wife again now.

sp.speaker: Castr.
sp.p: See how he notes the other now he feeds.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Give me some porridge.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I'll give thee none.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Give me some porridge.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I'll not give thee a bit,

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Give me that flap-dragon.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I'll not give thee a spoonful: thou liest, it's no dragon 'tis a parrot, that I bought for my sweet heart, and I'll keep it.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Here's an almond for parrot.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Hang thyself.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Here's a rope for parrot.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Eat it, for I'll eat this.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: I'll shoot at thee and though't give me none.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Wilt thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: I'll run a tilt at thee and though't give me none.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Wilt thou? do and thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: Bounce.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: Oh! I am slain murder—, murder, murder, I am slain, my brains are beaten out.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: How now you villains, bring me whips: I'll whip you

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I am dead, I am slain, ring out the bell, for I am dead,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: How will you do now sirrah? you ha' killed him.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: I'll answer't at sessions: he was eating of almond butter, and I longed for't: the child had never been delivered out of my belly, if I had not killed him I'll answer't at sessions, so my wife may be burned ith' hand too.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Take 'em in both: bury him, for he's dead.

sp.speaker: 3. Mad.
sp.p: I indeed, I am dead, put me I pray into a good pit hole.

sp.speaker: 2. Mad.
sp.p: I'll answer't at sessions. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: How now housewife, whether gad you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A nutting forsooth: how do you gaffer? how do you gaffer? there's a French curtsy for you too.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.p: 'Tis Bellafronte.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: 'Tis the punk byth' lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Father what's she I pray?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As yet I know not,
She came but in this day, talks little idly
And therefore has the freedom of the house,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do not you know me? nor you? nor you, nor you?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you are an ass, and you are an ass, and you are an ass, for I know you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: Why, what are they? come: tell me, what are they?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They're fishwives: will you buy any gudgeons, gods santy yonder come friars, I know them too, how do you friar?

div.stage: Enter Hipolito, Mathaeo, and Infaeliche disguised in the habets of friars.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay, nay, away, you must not trouble friars.
The Duke is here speak nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay indeed you shall not go: we'll run at barleybreak first, and you shall be in hell.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: My punk turned mad whore, as all her fellows are?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Speak nothing, but steal hence, when you spy time.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.p: I'll lock you up if you're unruly fie

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fie! marry so: they shall not go indeed till I ha' told 'em their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Good father give her leave.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I pray, good father, and I'll give you my blessing.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Well then be brief, but if you are thus unruly,
I'll have you locked up fast.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.p: Come, to their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let me see 1.2.3. and 4. I'll begin with the little friar first, here's a fine hand indeed, I never saw friar have such a dainty hand: here's a hand for a lady, here's your fortune,

lg.l: You love a friar better than a nun,
Yet long you'll love no friar, nor no friar's son.
Bow a little, the line of life is out, yet I'm afraid,
For all your holy, you'll not die a maid, God give you joy.
Now to you friar Tucke.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.p: God send me good luck.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You love one, and one loves you.
You are a false knave, and she's a Jew,
Here is a dial that false ever goes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O your wit drops.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Troth so does your nose, nay let's shake hands with you too:
Pray open, here's a fine hand,
Ho friar ho, God be here,
So he had need: you'll keep good cheer,
Here's a free table, but a frozen breast,
For you'll starve those that love you best.
Yet you have good fortune, for if I am no liar,
Than you are no friar, nor you, nor you no friarDiscovers them
Haha haha.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Are holy habits cloaks for villainy?
Draw all your weapons.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Do, draw all your weapons.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Where are your weapons, draw.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: The friar has gulled us of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O rare trick:
You ha' learned one mad point of arithmetic.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why swells your spleen so high? against what bosom,
Would you your weapons draw? hers! 'tis your daughters:
Mine! 'tis your sons.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Son?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Son, by yonder sun.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You cannot shed blood here, but 'tis your own,
To spill your own blood were damnation,
Lay smooth that wrinkled brow, and I will throw
Myself beneath your feet,
Let it be rugged still and flinted o'er,
What can come forth but sparkles, that will burn,
Yourself and us? She's mine; my claim's most good,
She's mine by marriage, though she's yours by blood.
I have a hand dear lord, deep in this act,
For I foresaw this storm, yet willingly
Put fourth to meet it? Oft have I seen a father
Washing the wounds of his dear son in tears,
A son to curse the sword that struck his father,
both slain ith' quarrel of your families,
Those scars are now ta'en off: and I beseech you,
To seal our pardon, all was to this end
To turn the ancient hates of your two houses
To fresh green friendship, that your loves might look:
Like the spring's forehead, comfortably sweet,
And your vexed souls in peaceful union meet,
Their blood will now be yours, yours will be theirs,
And happiness shall crown your silver hairs.

sp.speaker: Flu.
sp.l: You see my lord there's now no remedy.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: You beseech fair, you have me in place fit
To bridle me, rise friar. you may be glad
You can make madmen tame, and tame men mad,
Since fate hath conquered, I must rest content,
To strive now would but add new punishment:
I yield unto your happiness, be blessed,
Our families shall henceforth breathe in rest.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: O happy change.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Yours now is my consent,
I throw upon your joys my full consent.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Am not I a good girl, for finding the friar in the well? gods so you are a brave man: will not you buy me some sugar plums because I am so good a fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Would thou hadst wit thou pretty soul to ask,
As I have will to give.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pretty soul, a pretty soul is better than a pretty body: do not you know my pretty soul? I know you: is not your name Mathaeo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes lamb.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Baa, lamb! there you lie for I am mutton; look fine man, he was mad for me once, and I was mad for him once, and he was mad for her once, and were you never mad? yes I warrant, I had a fine jewel once, a very fine jewel and that naughty man stole it away from me, a very fine jewel.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What jewel pretty maid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Maid nay that's a lie, oh 'twas a very rich jewel, called
a maidenhead, and had not you it leerer.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Out you mad ass away.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Had he thy maidenhead? he shall make thee amends, and marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Shall he? O brave Arthur of Bradly then?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: And if he bear the mind of a gentleman,
I know he will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I think I rifled her of some such paltry jewel.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Did you? then marry her, you see the wrong
Has led her spirits into a lunacy.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How, marry her my lord? 'sfoot marry a madwoman: let a man get the tamest wife he can come by, she'll be mad enough afterwards, do what he can.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay then, father Anselmo here shall do his best,
To bring her to her wits, and will you then?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot tell, I may choose.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay then law shall compel: I tell you sir,
So much her hard fate moves me: you should not breathe I'll marry her.
Under this air, unless you married her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well then, when her wits stand in their right place,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I thank your grace, Mathaeo thou art mine,
I am not mad, but put on this disguise,
Only for you my lord, for you can tell
Much wonder of me, but you are gone: farewell.
Mathaeo thou didst first turn my soul black,
Now make it white again ▪ I do protest,
I'm pure as fire now, chaste as Cynthia's breast.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I durst be sworn Mathaeo she's indeed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Coney-catched, gulled, must I sail in your flyboat,
Because I helped to rear your mainmast first:
Plague found you fort, - 'tis well.
The cuckold's stamp goes currant in all nations,
Some men have horns given them at their creations,
If I be one of those, why so: it's better
To take a common wench, and make her good,
Than one that simpers and at first, will scarce
Be tempted forth over the threshold door,
Yet in one seven-night ●ounds, turns arrant whore,
come wench, thou shalt be mine, give me thy golls,
We'll talk of legs hereafter: see my lord,
God give us joy.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Come mistress we are in bedlam now, mass and see, we come in pudding-time, for here's the Duke.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: My husband good my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Have I thy husband?

sp.speaker: Ca●●.
sp.p: It's Candido my lord, he's here among the lunatics: father Anselmo, pray fetch him forth: this mad woman is his wife, and though she were not with child, yet did she long most spitefully to have her husband mad, and because she would be sure, he should turn Jew, she placed him here in Bethlem, yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come hither signior — are you mad.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: You are not mad.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why I know that.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Then may you know, I am not mad, that know
You are not mad, and that you are the Duke:
None is mad here but one — how do you wife:
What do you long for now? — pardon my lord,
She had lost her child's nose else: I did cut out
Pennyworths of lawn, the lawn was yet mine own:
A carpet was yet my gown, yet 'twas mine own,
I wore my man's coat ▪ yet the cloth mine own,
Had a cracked crown the crown was yet mine own,
She says for this I'm mad, were her words true,
I should be mad indeed — o foolish skill,
Is patience madness? I'll be a madman still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Forgive me, and I'll vex your spirit no more.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come, come, we'll have you friends, join hearts, join hands.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: See my lord, we are even,
Nay rise, for ill-deeds kneel unto none but heaven.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Signior, methinks , patience has laid on you
Such heavy weight, that you should loathe it.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: Loath it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: For he whose breast is tender blood so cool,
That no wrongs heat it, is a patient fool,
What comfort do you find in being so calm.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.l: That which green wounds receive from sovereign balm,
Patience my lord; why 'tis the soul of peace:
Of all the virtues 'tis near'st kin to heaven.
It makes men look like gods; the best of men
That ere wore earth about him, was a sufferer,
A soft, meek, patient, humble, tranquil spirit,
The first true gentleman that ever breathed;
The stock of patience then cannot be poor,
All it desires, it has; what monarch more?
It is the greatest enemy to law
That can be, for it doth embrace all wrongs,
And so chains up, lawyers and women's tongues.
'Tis the perpetual prisoner's liberty:
His walks and orchards: 'tis the bondslaves's freedom,
And makes him seem proud of each iron chain.
As though he wore it more for state than pain:
It is the beggar's music, and thus sings,
Although their bodies beg, their souls are Kings:
Oh my dread liege! It is the sap of bliss,
Rears us aloft; makes men and angels kiss,
And (Last of all) to end a household strife,
It is the honey 'gainst a waspish wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou giv'st it lively colours: who dare say
He's mad, whose words march in so good array?
'Twere sin all women should such husbands have.
For every man must then be his wife's slave.
Come therefore you shall teach our court to shine,
So calm a spirit is worth a golden mine,
Wiues (With meek husbands) that to vex them long,
In bedlam must they dwell, else dwell they wrong.
